PART II - CODE OF THE CITY
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) ---
State Law reference— Municipal home rule, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 2; O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; exemplification
of municipal minutes and other records, O.C.G.A. § 24-7-21; authority to adopt ordinances, resolutions or regulations,
O.C.G.A. § 36-35-3.
Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited.
The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the ``Code of the City of
Cordele,'' and may be so cited.
(Code 1977, § 1-1)
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction.
In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless the context clearly
indicates otherwise:
Bond. When a bond is required by law, an undertaking in writing, without seal, is sufficient; in all bonds where the names
of the obligors do not appear in the bond, but are subscribed thereto, they shall be bound thereby.
Charter. ``Charter'' means the Charter of the City of Cordele, Georgia as printed in Part I of this volume.
City. The words ``the city'' or ``this city'' shall be construed as if the words ``of Cordele'' followed them and shall extend to
and include its several officers, agents and employees.
City commission. Whenever the words ``city commission'' are used, they shall be construed to mean the city commission of
the City of Cordele.
City officers, boards, commissions, etc. Whenever reference is made to officers, boards, commissions, etc., by title only,
i.e., ``city clerk,'' ``chief of police,'' etc., they shall be deemed to refer to the officers, boards, commission, etc., of the City
of Cordele.
Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done, a certain length of time before any
proceedings shall be had, the day on which such notice is given, or such act is done, shall be counted in computing the
time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall not be counted.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
35/489
Corporate limits. ``Corporate limits'' means the corporate limits of the City of Cordele.
County. The words ``the county'' or ``this county'' shall mean the County of Crisp, in the State of Georgia.
Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision requires the head of a department or an official of the city to do some act or
perform some function, it shall be construed to authorize the head of such department or the official to designate, delegate
and authorize subordinates to do the required act or perform the required function, unless the terms of the provisions
designate otherwise.
Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and
corporations as well as to males.
Governor. ``Governor'' means the governor of the State of Georgia.
Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum
requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any
provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provisions imposed by the
Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction shall be deemed to be controlling.
Joint authority. A joint authority given to any number of persons or officers may be executed by a majority of them, unless
it is otherwise declared.
Legislative intent. In all interpretations of this Code or of ordinances or resolutions, the courts shall look diligently for the
intention of the board of commissioners, keeping in mind at all times the old law, the civil and the remedy. Grammatical
errors shall not vitiate any provision, and a transposition of words and phrases may be resorted to when a clause or
sentence is without meaning as it stands.
Month, year. ``Month'' and ``year'' mean calendar month and calendar year unless otherwise provided.
Names of officers, departments. The name or title of any officer or department shall be read as though the words ``of the
City of Cordele'' were added thereto.
Nontechnical and technical words. The ordinary significance shall be applied to all words, except words of art, or words
connected with a particular trade or subject matter, in which case they shall have the significance attached to them by
experts in such trade, or with reference to such subject matter.
Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to
one (1) person and thing.
Oath. The word ``oath'' shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be
substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words ``swear'' and ``sworn'' shall be equivalent to the words ``affirm'' and
``affirmed.''
Or, and. ``Or'' may be read ``and,'' and ``and'' may be read ``or'' if the sense requires it.
Owner. The word ``owner,'' applied to a building or land shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common,
tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, copartnerships of the whole or of a part of such building or
land.
Person. The word ``person'' shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships, copartnerships
and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals, including the officers of such associations, corporations, etc.
Personal property. ``Personal property'' includes every species of property except real property.
Preceding and following. ``Preceding'' and ``following'' mean generally next before and next after unless the context
requires a different significance.
Property. ``Property'' includes real and personal property.
Real property. ``Real property'' includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
36/489
Requirements. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum
requirement adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any
provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than another more general provision, the
provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed controlling.
Residence. ``Residence'' means the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation and to which, whenever he is
absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such
person sleeps shall be deemed his residence.
Right-of-way. ``Right-of-way'' means land that is dedicated or otherwise legally established for public use.
Roadway. ``Roadway'' means that portion of a street improved, designated or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic.
Schedule of fees and charges. ``Schedule of fees and charges'' means the official, consolidated list compiled and published
by the city which contains rates for utility and other public enterprises, fees, deposit amounts and various charges as
determined from time to time by the city commission, an official copy of which is maintained in the office of the city clerk
where it is available for reference and review during normal business hours.
Shall; may. The word ``shall'' is always mandatory and not merely directory; ``may'' is permissive.
Sidewalk. ``Sidewalk'' means that portion of the street right-of-way which is improved and designated for the use of
pedestrians.
Signature or subscription. A ``signature'' or ``subscription'' includes the mark of an illiterate or infirm person.
State. The words ``the state'' or ``this state'' shall be construed to mean the State of Georgia.
Statute references. Whenever reference is made, for example, to O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3, it shall be construed to refer to the
Official Code of Georgia Annotated, § 1-3-3, as amended, or to whatever section is cited.
Street. ``Street'' means and includes any public way, road, highway, street, avenue, alley, boulevard, parkway, lane, path,
viaduct, bridge or any other name a street is commonly known by, or any public place and the approaches thereto within
the city when any part thereof is open to the use of the public and established for purposes of vehicular traffic.
Substantial compliance. A substantial compliance with any requirement of this Code or ordinances amendatory hereof,
especially on the part of public officers, shall be deemed and held sufficient; and no proceeding shall be declared void for
want of such compliance, unless expressly so provided.
Tenant, occupant. The word ``tenant'' or ``occupant,'' applied to a building or land, includes any person who occupies the
whole or part of such building or land, whether alone or with others.
Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and the present.
Time. Words used in the present or past tense include the future as well as the present or past.
Title of office. The title of any office shall be construed to include the words ``of the City of Cordele, Georgia.''
Writing, written. The word ``writing'' or ``written'' includes printing and all numerals, and also pictures, illustrations and
printed or written designs.
Year. ``Year'' means calendar year.
(Code 1977, § 1-2)
State law reference— Computation of time, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1; construction of definitions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-2; meaning of
certain words, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; time, O.C.G.A. § 9-11-6.
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections.
(a)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
37/489
The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the
contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be the titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor,
unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or
reenacted.
(b)
The history notes appearing in parentheses after each section and the references and editor's notes scattered throughout the
Code are for the benefit of the user of the Code and shall have no legal effect.
State law reference— Notes and catchlines of code sections not part of law, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-7.
Sec. 1-4. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language.
(a)
All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code of Ordinances which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code of
Ordinances, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein.
When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may
be excluded from this Code by omission from reprinted pages.
(b)
Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the
section number of this Code in the following language: ``That section ;#rule; of the Code of the City of Cordele is hereby
amended to read as follows: ….'' The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired.
(c)
In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code, is to be added, the following language shall be used: ``That
the Code of the City of Cordele is hereby amended by adding a section to be numbered ;#rule;, which such section reads as
follows: ….'' The new section shall then be set out in full as desired.
(d)
All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or
chapter number, as the case may be.
(Code 1977, § 1-4)
Sec. 1-5. - Supplementation of Code.
(a)
By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared on an annual basis. A supplement to the Code
shall include all substantive, permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council during the period
covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that
they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages that have become obsolete or partially
obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the
date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement.
(b)
In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code
by the omission thereof from reprinted pages.
(c)
When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare
the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the
supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may:
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
38/489
(1)
Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions.
(2)
Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the
supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles.
(3)
Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to
accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers.
(4)
Change the words ``this ordinance'' or words of the same meaning to ``this chapter,'' ``this article,'' ``this division,'' etc., as
the case may be, or to ``sections ;#rule; to ;#rule;'' (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which
embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code).
(5)
Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meanings of ordinance sections inserted into the
Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the
supplement or already embodied in the Code.
Sec. 1-6. - Altering Code.
It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this
Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever
which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby.
(Code 1977, § 1-5)
State law reference— Altering, falsifying or stealing public records unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-1.
Sec. 1-7. - Ordinances not affected by Code.
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any
of the following:
(1)
Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing
before the effective date of this Code.
(2)
Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of
any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness.
(3)
Any contract or obligation assumed by the city.
(4)
Any ordinance fixing the salary of any city officer or employee.
(5)
Any right or franchise granted by the city.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
39/489
(6)
Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public
way in the city.
(7)
Any appropriation ordinance.
(8)
Any ordinance which, by its own terms, is effective for a stated or limited term.
(9)
Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor.
(10)
Any zoning ordinance.
(11)
Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat.
(12)
Any ordinance describing or altering the boundaries of the city.
(13)
The administrative ordinances or resolutions of the city not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code.
(14)
Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not included herein.
(15)
Any ordinance establishing or prescribing street grades in the city.
Nor such ordinance shall be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent
ordinance which is repealed by this chapter; and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and
effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein.
Sec. 1-8. - Provisions considered continuations of existing ordinances.
The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as ordinances adopted prior to this Code and included in
such Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments.
Sec. 1-9. - Effect of repeal of ordinances.
(a)
The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect.
(b)
The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit,
prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or matter covered under the
ordinance repealed.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
40/489
Sec. 1-10. - City property outside city limits.
All ordinances which are in force within the limits of the city shall be in force and of full effect on any park or airport or
any other property of the city located outside of the city limits of the city wherever the ordinance is applicable.
State law reference— Acquisition, construction and maintenance of airports by municipalities authorized, O.C.G.A. § 6-
3-20; powers and duties of municipalities as to airports, O.C.G.A. § 6-3-25.
Sec. 1-11. - Liability for violations by corporations, other associations.
(a)
Any violation of this Code by any officer, agent or other person acting for or employed by any corporation or
unincorporated association or organization, while acting within the scope of his office or employment, shall in every case
also be deemed to be a violation by such corporation, association or organization.
(b)
Any officer, agent or other person acting for or employed by any corporation or unincorporated association or organization
shall be subject and liable to punishment as well as such corporation or unincorporated association or organization for the
violation by it of any provisions of this Code, where such violation was the act or omission, or the result of the act,
omission or order, of any such person.
Sec. 1-12. - Severability of parts of Code.
It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city commission that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases
of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code is declared
unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such
unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences,
paragraphs and sections of this Code.
State law reference— Severability, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-3.
Sec. 1-13. - General penalty; continuing violations; adjudging fines and imprisonments.
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any provision of this Code and where no specific
penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any provision of this Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment or labor on streets, roads and public works, for a term not exceeding six (6)
months, either one (1) or more or a combination of such punishments. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code
shall continue shall constitute a separate offense.
(Code 1977, § 1-6)
State law reference— Penalty to be imposed in certain criminal and traffic cases and upon violation of bond, O.C.G.A. §
15-21-73; authority to confine persons convicted of violating ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-8; punishments authorized,
O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1(c); limitations on home rule powers, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6; revenues collected from fines and fees,
O.C.G.A. § 47-17-60 et seq.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances

Editor's note— The city's block grant ordinance was published in the 1977 Code as sections 7.5-16 through 7.5-22 and
was amended by ordinance number 0-83-29 enacted December 20, 1983. A copy of the ordinance and amendment is on file
in the city clerk's office where it is available for reference and review during normal business hours.
Sec. 2-1. - Official map of survey of city.
(a)
The official map of the city is the latest survey adopted by the city commission.
(b)
The boundaries of this city at all times shall be shown on such map which shall be retained permanently in the office of the
city clerk. Photographic, typed or other copies of such map or description certified by the city clerk shall be admitted as
evidence in all courts and shall have the same force and effect as the original map or description.
(c)
The city commission may provide for the redrawing of any such map by ordinance to reflect lawful changes in the
corporate boundaries. A redrawn map shall supersede for all purposes the entire map which it is designated to replace.
(d)
The city hereby expressly accepts the dedication for public purpose of all public areas implied to be thus dedicated by all
private indentures conveying land by reference to any previous map, survey, or plat of the city adopted or used by the city.
(Code 1977, § 1-7)
Secs. 2-2—2-25. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-26. - Commission meetings.
The city commission will meet in regular public meeting sessions on the first and third Tuesdays of each month, in the city
hall.
(Code 1977, § 2-1)
Sec. 2-27. - Failure to obey order of commission.
(a)
Any person who fails or refuses to obey a lawful order of the city commission in the exercise of powers granted the
commission under section 2.24 of the city charter shall, upon conviction in the city criminal court be punished in
accordance with section 1-13
(b)
The term "lawful order" as used in this section, includes, but is not limited to, subpoenas, notices for the production of
evidence, and notices to appear before the commission at a time and place certain.

ARTICLE III. - DEPARTMENTS
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (4) ---
State Law reference— Authorization to establish municipal offices, agencies and employments, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2(1).
Sec. 2-46. - Established, enumerated.
Under the authority granted to the city commission by sections 2.12(c) and 3.10 of the city charter (Ga.L., 1969, pp. 3824
and 3831), the following departments of the city are herewith established:
(1)
Public works department.
(2)
Sanitation department.
(3)
Finance department.
(4)
Utility control and treatment department.
(5)
Community development department.
(6)
Personnel and human resources department.
(7)
Public safety department.
(8)
Police department.
(9)
Fire department.
(Ord. No. 0-84-2, § 1, 1-17-84)
Sec. 2-47. - Administrative control.
Each of the departments of the city shall be under the general administrative control of a person who shall be employed in
strict accordance with the personnel plan of the city.
(Ord. No. 0-84-2, § 2, 1-17-84)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
43/489
Sec. 2-48. - Titles of department heads.
The police department shall be under the direction and control of the police chief. The fire department shall be under the
direction and control of the fire chief. All other city departments shall be under the direction and control of a director. The
job title of each director shall be: Director, public works department; director, sanitation department; etc. Each director is
under the supervision and control of the city manager.
(Ord. No. 0-84-2, § 5, 1-17-84)
Sec. 2-49. - Authority, responsibility of heads, manager.
Each person mentioned in section 2-48 is responsible to the city manager (charter, section 3.20, Ga.L., 1969, p. 3832) who,
in turn, has the authority and responsibility set forth in section 3.22 of the charter (Ga.L., 1969, pp. 3832, 3833).
(Ord. No. 0-84-2, § 3, 1-17-84)
Sec. 2-50. - Functions, duties—Generally.
The broad functions and duties of the departments established in this article are as follows:
(1)
Public works department. Effective administration, control and operation of the operations department, city garage, parks
and cemeteries, street department and utility distribution.
(2)
Sanitation department. Effective administration, control and operation of garbage and trash collection.
(3)
Finance department. Effective administration, control and operation of accounting, records and files of budget and fiscal
affairs.
(4)
Utility control and treatment. Effective administration, control and operation of the wastewater treatment plant, the water
system and the sewer system.
(5)
Community development director/chief code official. Effective administration, control and operation of the city's
community development involving codes implementation and enforcement, planning, zoning, subdivision regulations,
economic development, civic/cultural affairs, recreation, chamber of commerce, social programs, housing, grants,
coordination with state and federal agencies, and related functions.
(6)
Personnel and human resources department. Effective administration, control and operation of all phases of personnel
relations, including but not limited to the personnel plan, JMERS retirement plan, group health and life insurance and
affirmative action coordination for EEOC policies and programs.
(7)
Public safety department.
(8)
Police department. Effective administration, control and operation of the police department, civil defense functions and
animal control operations.
(9)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
44/489
Fire department. Effective administration, control and operation of the fire department.
(Ord. No. 0-84-2, § 4, 1-17-84)
Sec. 2-51. - Same—Implementation.
The city manager shall implement the broad functions and duties of the various departments through the various directors
and chiefs, and in furtherance thereof shall assign in detail the functions and duties of such directors and chiefs required, as
in his managerial judgment, to carry out the spirit and intent of this article.
(Ord. No. 0-84-2, § 6, 1-17-84)
Sec. 2-52. - Organization chart.
The broad organizational chart of the city, down to the departments created in this article, is on file in the city clerk's office
where it is available for inspection and review. The city manager is authorized to adopt further details of the city's
administrative organization as in his judgment appears proper, provided that prior approval of the same is obtained from
the city commission, with such approval recorded in the minutes of the commission.
(Ord. No. 0-84-2, § 8, 1-17-84)
Sec. 2-53. - Changes in personnel plan; reorganization.
The city manager is directed to recommend changes in the personnel plan to the city commission from time to time so as to
obtain prior commission approval of departmental reorganizations, it being anticipated by the commission that such will be
needed to refine city operations toward the objectives of economical, effective, publicly acceptable city services to our
citizens.
(Ord. No. 0-84-2, § 7, 1-17-84)
Secs. 2-54—2-70. - Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. - CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (5) ---
State Law reference— Power of expenditure, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 4, par. 2; discretion of governing body as to
management and disposition of property, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-2; acquisition, sale and lease of real and personal property,
O.C.G.A. § 36-37-1; disposition of municipal property, O.C.G.A. § 36-37-6; multiyear lease, purchase or lease purchase
contracts, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-13; budgets and audits, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-1 et seq.; accounting for public funds, O.C.G.A. §
45-8-1 et seq.; local political subdivision purchases, O.C.G.A. § 50-5-100 et seq.
Sec. 2-71. - Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section,
except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
City contract means any contract for construction for the city or negotiated by the city for the benefit of the public or an
individual, firm or corporation, regardless of whether or not the city is a party to the contract.
Construction means improvements or repairs the objective of which is to build, install, repair or improve a permanent
structure, location, system, or device with lumber, masonry, concrete, asphalt, rock, gravel, metal, plastic, glass or other
similar material, to include necessary machinery, appliances or other fixtures and devices necessary for proper completion
of such improvements or repairs.
Permanent means having a useful life of five (5) years or more.
(Ord. No. 0-89-28, § 2.25, 11-21-89)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
45/489
Sec. 2-72. - Bids required.
Every city contract in the amount of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) and over shall require competitive bidding.
(Ord. No. 0-89-28, § 2.26, 11-21-89; Ord. No. 0-00-06, § 1, 3-7-00)
Sec. 2-73. - Application of state law.
O.C.G.A. § 13-10-1, as the same may hereafter be amended, shall apply to all city construction contracts within limits
specified therein.
(Ord. No. 0-89-28, § 2.27, 11-21-89)
Sec. 2-74. - Invitation to bid; advertisement.
No city construction contract within the regulation of this article shall be entered into until an "Invitation To Bid" has been
published at least two (2) times one (1) week apart in the official organ of the city. The invitation will state the nature of the
work to be performed; the project description, if applicable; and the location at the city hall where specifications for the
work, bid documents and bid requirements may be obtained.
(Ord. No. 0-89-28, § 2.28, 11-21-89)
Sec. 2-75. - Bid bonds or other security.
(a)
In every instance where the city is seeking a contract subject to this article no bid shall be considered unless the contractor
shall give a bid bond with good and sufficient surety approved by the city commission for the faithful acceptance of the
contract, payable to the city and for the protection of the city and the person for which the city seeks to contract. The bid
bond shall be in the amount of not less than five (5) percent of the total payable by the terms of the contract.
(b)
In lieu of the bid bond provided for in subsection (a) of this section, a cashier's check, certified check or cash, will be
accepted by the city, in such amount, payable and for the protection aforesaid.
(Ord. No. 0-89-28, § 2.29, 11-21-89)
Sec. 2-76. - Performance bond; payment bond.
(a)
Every contractor subject to the provisions of this article shall furnish a performance bond with good and sufficient surety
payable to, in favor of, and for the protection of the city and/or the person for whom the work is to be done. The
performance bond shall be in the amount of at least the total amount payable by the terms of the contract.
(b)
Every contractor subject to provisions of this article shall furnish a payment bond with good and sufficient surety payable
to the city and/or the person for whom the work is to be done, and for the use and protection of all subcontractors and all
persons supplying labor, materials, machinery, and equipment in the prosecution of the work provided for in the contract.
The payment bond shall be in the amount of at least the total amount payable by the terms of the contract.
(c)
In lieu of either or both of the bonds provided for in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the city may accept a cashier's
check, certified check or cash in the amount of either or both of the otherwise required bonds for the use and protection
aforesaid.
(Ord. No. 0-89-28, § 2.30, 11-21-89)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
46/489
Sec. 2-77. - Workers' compensation insurance required.
All contractors performing work subject to this article shall have workers' compensation insurance within limits required
by the laws of the state.
(Ord. No. 0-89-28, § 2.31, 11-21-89)
Sec. 2-78. - Vehicle liability insurance required.
All contractors performing work subject to this article shall have vehicle liability insurance on each vehicle used in the
work, with limits not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00)/three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00)
personal injury and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) property damage.
(Ord. No. 0-89-28, § 2.32, 11-21-89)
Sec. 2-79. - Public liability insurance required.
All contractors performing work subject to this article shall have public liability insurance with limits not less than one
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) personal injury and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) property damage.
(Ord. No. 0-89-28, § 2.33, 11-21-89)
Sec. 2-80. - Period of insurance coverage; additional insured; copies.
Insurance required by this article shall be effective for the time required to complete the city contract. With the exception
of workers' compensation insurance, the city and/or the party for who the city has arranged the work shall be listed as an
additional insured. Copies of insurance policies evidencing compliance with this article must be furnished to the city prior
to commencing contract performance.
(Ord. No. 0-89-28, § 2.34, 11-21-89)
Sec. 2-81. - Bonds; acceptability.
(a)
All bonds required by this article shall be obtained from companies holding certificates of authority as acceptable sureties,
currently listed as such in federal publications.
(b)
This article is adopted as a policy of the city, except for sections 2-75 and 2-76, until such time that the provisions aforesaid
are adopted in final ordinance form and mandatory as an amendment to the Code of the City of Cordele.
(Ord. No. 0-89-28, § 2.35, 11-21-89)
Secs. 2-82—2-100. - Reserved.
ARTICLE V. - ELECTIONS
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (6) ---
State Law reference— Georgia Municipal Election Code, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-1 et seq.
Sec. 2-101. - Election officials.
The following offices are hereby created in connection with the conduct of elections for the city:
(1)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
47/489
Superintendent. The city commission shall appoint a municipal election superintendent who shall receive such
compensation as provided by the city commission. The municipal election superintendent may be the city clerk, some other
city employee, or a private citizen of the city, provided such person appointed is not disqualified by provisions of the
Georgia Municipal Election Code. Nothing in this subsection shall prohibit the appointment of a city employee as
superintendent as an additional duty without extra compensation therefor. The superintendent shall exercise those powers
and perform those duties as set forth in the Georgia Municipal Election Code. In addition, the superintendent shall perform
the following duties:
a.
At least forty-five (45) days before each election for a city commissioner the superintendent shall advertise for applications
of persons interested in being employed as election managers, election clerks, and city election registrars, setting forth such
qualifications as may be provided for city poll workers by this Code and the Georgia Municipal Election Code. The
advertisement provided by this subsection shall be in a newspaper having general circulation in the city.
b.
If from applications received, the superintendent determines that an insufficient number of black or white applicants are
available to provide employment of poll workers in black-white proportion to black-white registered voters in the city, the
superintendent shall actively recruit applicants so that such prorata representation may be accomplished.
c.
The superintendent shall then present two (2) lists of poll worker applicants, one (1) black and one (1) white, to the city
commission for its official appointment of election managers, election clerks and city election registrars.
d.
The city commission shall, from the two (2) lists presented, appoint the election managers, election clerks, and city election
registrars in legally required or otherwise sufficient numbers to properly conduct the upcoming election. Appointments
shall be made in each of such categories, as nearly as possible, in percentile proportion to the black-white registered voters
qualified to cast ballots in the upcoming election.
e.
In the event of a special election, the superintendent may shorten the advertisement time before such special election and
the above procedure for final selection shall be followed; however, should the lead time for any such special election not
permit such procedure, available poll workers from the previous election shall be employed and the superintendent shall, if
necessary, actively recruit applicants to insure the racial balance required by this section.
f.
It shall be unlawful to violate any provision of this section, and as to any such violation the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 21-
3-477 and 21-3-478 shall apply.
State law reference— Requirement to select superintendent, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-8(3).
(2)
Chief manager. A chief manager for each election district shall be appointed by the city commission for each election. A
chief manager shall receive such compensation as provided by the city commission, and his powers and duties shall be as
set forth for chief managers in the Georgia Municipal Election Code.
State law reference— Appointment of chief manager and assistant managers, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-32.
(3)
Assistant managers. Two (2) assistant managers for each election district shall be appointed by the city commission for
each election. The assistant managers shall receive such compensation as provided by the city commission, and their
powers and duties shall be as provided by the Georgia Municipal Election Code.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
48/489
(4)
Clerks. Prior to the opening of the polls in each election district, the city commission shall appoint a sufficient number of
clerks to serve at such election. The clerks shall receive such compensation as provided by the city commission, and their
powers and duties shall be as provided by the Georgia Municipal Election Code.
(Code 1977, § 9-3; Ord. No. 0-88-5, § 9-3, 2-23-88; Ord. No. 0-93-15, § 1, 9-7-93)
Sec. 2-102. - Election expenses.
The election superintendent is authorized to incur expenses in the preparation and conduct of an election including the cost
of purchasing identification badges for polling officers, the printing of ballots and voter certificates, and the purchase of all
other supplies necessary for the conduct of an election. The superintendent is further authorized to incur all necessary
expense in providing voting booths and voting machines for the proper conduct of all elections.
(Code 1977, § 9-4(a))
State law reference— Requirement to budget and appropriate funds for the conduct of elections, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-8.
Sec. 2-103. - Voting machines.
The city commission hereby directs the use of voting machines for recording and computing the vote at all elections held in
the city, as provided by O.C.G.A. § 21-3-220.
(Code 1977, § 9-4(b))
State law reference— Authorization to procure and use voting machines, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-220.
Sec. 2-104. - City to use county registration system.
The city shall use the registration system of the county, and the county registrar shall carry out the functions necessary for
municipal registration and shall maintain all registration cards, and his office shall be deemed the main registration office,
all as provided by the Georgia Municipal Election Code.
(Code 1977, § 9-6(b))
State law reference— City may elect either to maintain its own registration or to provide for the city to use the county
registration list, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-125(d).
Sec. 2-105. - City registrars.
The city commission shall appoint registrars as necessary, and such appointments shall be entered upon the minutes of the
city commission. The city commission shall designate one (1) of the registrars as chief registrar for such term of office as
the commission sees fit, and such designation and term shall likewise be entered upon the minutes of the commission. The
registrars, and the chief registrar, shall serve at the pleasure of the city commission, and compensation for same shall be
fixed by the city commission. Changes in registrars, and the chief registrar, by removal, resignation, or otherwise, shall be
entered in the minutes of the commission, and shall be as provided by the Georgia Municipal Election Code.
(Code 1977, § 9-6(d))
State law reference— Appointment and compensation of registrars and deputy registrars, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-120.
Sec. 2-106. - Oath of city registration officers.
Before entering upon his duties, each registrar and deputy registrar shall swear to faithfully perform his duties, which oath
shall be administered by some officer authorized to administer oaths under the laws of the state.
(Code 1977, § 9-6(d)(2))
Sec. 2-107. - Voters list.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
49/489
The chief city registrar shall, upon receipt of the county registration list, or as soon as practicable thereafter but in no event
later than three (3) days prior to an election, purge such list of the names of all persons who will not be qualified to vote at
such election. The chief city registrar shall certify the list and file a copy with the city clerk showing the names of electors,
alphabetically arranged, who are entitled to vote at such election.
(Code 1977, § 9-6(e))
State law reference— Filing of certified list of qualified voters with city clerk, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-135.
Sec. 2-108. - Nomination of candidates.
Any person qualified according to the charter of the city and the laws of the state, and desiring to run for the office of city
commissioner, shall notify the election superintendent within the time prescribed herein, by written affidavit in the form
prescribed by O.C.G.A. § 21-3-91(c), and the manner in which his or her name is to appear on the ballot. Such person shall
pay the three (3) percent qualifying fee required by O.C.G.A. § 21-3-90(a), or file a pauper's affidavit in lieu thereof as
required by O.C.G.A. § 21-3-90(b).
(Code 1977, § 9-9; Ord. No. 0-93-15, § 2, 9-7-93)
Sec. 2-109. - Election of candidates; majority of votes cast.
No candidate shall be elected to public office in the city unless such candidate shall have received a majority of the votes
cast to fill such office. "Votes cast," as referred to in this section, shall be those votes which are valid and countable for a
candidate for such office. The city commission shall officially declare the results of every city election at the first regular or
special meeting of the commission following such election.
(Code 1977, § 9-10)
State law reference— Vote required for nomination or election, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-407.
Sec. 2-110. - Date of city elections; notice.
The date of the holding of elections for the office of city commissioners shall be in accordance with state law. Public notice
of such elections shall be published by the city commission in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, at least thirty
(30) days, but not more than forty (40) days, prior to such elections.
(Code 1977, § 9-12)
State law reference— Date of municipal elections, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-51.
Sec. 2-111. - Qualifications of candidates; time; advertisement.
(a)
At least two (2) weeks prior to the closing of qualification for an election for the office of city commissioner, the city
commission shall by resolution fix and publish a qualification fee to be paid by candidates seeking election to such office.
Such fee shall be paid to the election superintendent at the time candidate files his notice of candidacy. Such fee shall be
three (3) percent of the annual salary of the office of city commissioner.
(b)
Qualifications of candidates for the office of city commissioner shall be within the time set forth in O.C.G.A. § 21-3-91(a)
(1) and shall be for a period of five (5) working days ending at 12:00 noon of the fifth day.
(c)
The city commission shall cause to be advertised such qualifying fee or paupers affidavit and such qualifying time in a
newspaper of general circulation in the city at least two (2) weeks prior to the closing of qualifications for the office of city
commissioner.
(Code 1977, § 9-13; Ord. No. 0-93-15, § 3, 9-7-93)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
50/489
State law reference— Selection and qualification of candidates, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-90 et seq.
Sec. 2-112. - General elections.
All elections held for the purpose of filling the office of city commissioners in the city shall be general elections, and no
political party shall conduct primaries for the purpose of nominating candidates for such office.
(Code 1977, § 9-14)

ARTICLE VI. - INDEMNIFICATION OF OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (7) ---
State Law reference— Authorization of purchase by municipal corporations of insurance covering injuries resulting from
ownership of motor vehicles; waiver of governmental immunity; limitation of liabilities, O.C.G.A. § 33-24-51; immunity
of municipality from liability for damages; waiver of immunity by purchase of liability insurance, O.C.G.A. § 36-33-1;
personal liability of council members and other municipal officers, O.C.G.A. § 36-33-4.
Sec. 2-131. - Short title.
This article shall be known and may be cited as "The Personal Protection Ordinance."
(Ord. No. 0-80-5, § 1, 2-19-80)
Sec. 2-132. - Public purpose.
The public purpose of this article is to provide personal protection for elected and appointed officials of the city, as well as
city supervisors, administrators and employees, arising out of their duties or in any way connected therewith, whether
based upon negligence, violation of contract rights, or violation of civil, constitutional, common law or statutory rights.
Such purpose is declared necessary to obtain for the city a high quality of elected and appointed officials, supervisors,
administrators and employees necessary to carry out an effective, efficient operation of the city without danger of personal
liability in the exercise of reasonable judgment in the performance of their duties.
(Ord. No. 0-80-5, § 2, 2-19-80)
Sec. 2-133. - Benefits in addition to other compensation.
Any benefit provided by this article, either directly or indirectly, to any elected and appointed official of the city, and any
supervisor, administrator and employee of the city, shall be in addition to the regular compensation of any such individual,
and shall not be chargeable in any way to or against any such regular compensation; which is to say that the provisions of
this article are part of the compensation and terms of employment or election of each member of the city protected hereby.
(Ord. No. 0-80-5, § 3, 2-19-80)
Sec. 2-134. - Source of funds.
The city may lawfully expend any available city, state or federal funds to carry out the provisions of this article.
(Ord. No. 0-80-5, § 4, 2-19-80)
Sec. 2-135. - Exclusions.
This article, or no benefit hereunder, shall be used for the protection of any person charged with a criminal offense
involving theft, embezzlement or other like crime with respect to the property or money of or in which the city has an
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
51/489
interest.
(Ord. No. 0-80-5, § 5, 2-19-80)
Sec. 2-136. - Liability insurance or contracts of indemnity.
The city shall have of force and effect a liability insurance policy or contract of indemnity which shall protect members of
the city commission, other appointed and elected officials of the city, and supervisors, administrators and employees of the
city, against personal liability for damages arising out of the performance of their duties or in any way connected therewith
whether based upon negligence, violation of contract rights, or violation of civil, constitutional, common law or other
statutory rights, whether state, federal or local.
(Ord. No. 0-80-5, § 6, 2-19-80)
Sec. 2-137. - Defense of actions.
In addition to the protection afforded by the provisions of section 2-136 relating to the purchase of liability insurance or
indemnity contracts, the city commission hereby ordains that it is the policy of the city to defend all civil, criminal or
quasi-criminal actions brought or maintained against members of the commission, other elected or appointed officials of
the city, its supervisors, administrators and employees, whether or not such persons receive regular compensation from the
city, arising out of the performance of their duties or in any way connected therewith, whether based upon negligence,
violation of contract rights, or violation of civil, constitutional, common law or statutory rights; provided, however, that in
addition to section 2-135, the city shall not defend any person from any action based upon the allegation of libel or slander.
(Ord. No. 0-80-5, § 7, 2-19-80)
Sec. 2-138. - Payment of claims or judgments.
In addition to the protection afforded by the provisions of this article, the city commission further ordains that it is the
policy of the city to pay all of every judicially established claim or civil judgment rendered against any person whose
defense is authorized by the provisions of this article. Any such disbursements is deemed to be for public purposes and
may be paid from state, federal or city funds.
(Ord. No. 0-80-5, § 8, 2-19-80)
Sec. 2-139. - Nondisclosure.
This article shall not be disclosed or suggested in any action brought against any individual protected hereby. Nor shall this
article serve as the foundation of alleged justification for any action, counterclaim, cross claim or third party action in any
court.
(Ord. No. 0-80-5, § 9, 2-19-80)
Sec. 2-140. - Selection of counsel.
The city commission shall exclusively determine the attorney who may be required from time to time to carry out
provisions of this article. The city commission shall contract with such attorney who shall be directly responsible to the
commission. If any person protected hereby is dissatisfied with the services of any such attorney the remedy of such person
shall be limited to hiring an additional attorney at his own expense; however, any such person may, if he desires, waive the
protection of this article, in writing, to the commission, and the commission shall forthwith discharge the attorney retained
in the matter as to the waiving individual. Should such waiver be received by the commission, the waiving individual shall
not have the benefit of section 2-138, relating to payment of claims or judgments as to the particular action involved.
(Ord. No. 0-80-5, § 10, 2-19-80)
Sec. 2-141. - Expenditures authorized.
In addition to payments specifically authorized by this article in any other provision hereof, the city, for the purposes of this
article, may expend state, federal and city funds for attorney's fees, court costs, deposition costs, witness fees and
compensation, and all other like costs, expenses and fees, and for all other purposes determined by the city commission to
be necessary to carry out the spirit and intent of this article.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
52/489
(Ord. No. 0-80-5, § 11, 2-19-80)
Sec. 2-142. - Recovery of expenditures.
Wherever possible and to the fullest extent allowed by law the city shall recover payments made under this article from the
insurance or indemnity contract provided by section 2-136.
(Ord. No. 0-80-5, § 12, 2-19-80)
Secs. 2-143—2-160. - Reserved.
ARTICLE VII. - PERSONNEL
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (8) ---
State Law reference— City's power to define, regulate and alter the powers, duties, qualifications, compensation and
tenure of all municipal officers, agents and employees, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-2(2).
Sec. 2-161. - Short title.
The short title of this article shall be "The Personnel Ordinance," and it may be thus cited and designated for all legal and
informal purposes.
(Ord. No. 0-84-10, 3-20-84)
Sec. 2-162. - Purpose.
The general purpose of this article is to establish a system of personnel administration for the city. This system shall
provide means to recruit, select, develop and maintain an effective and responsible work force, and shall include policies
for employee hiring and advancement, training and career development, job classification, salary administration, fringe
benefits, discharge and other related activities. The system herein established will be consistent with such merit principles
as:
(1)
Recruiting, selecting, and advancing employees on the basis of their relative ability, knowledge, and skills, including open
consideration of qualified applicants for initial appointment.
(2)
Providing equitable and adequate compensation.
(3)
Training employees, as needed, to assure high-quality performance.
(4)
Retaining employees on the basis of the adequacy of their performance, correcting inadequate performance, and separating
employees whose inadequate performance cannot be corrected.
(5)
Assuring fair treatment of applicants and employees in all aspects of personnel administration without regard to political
affiliation, race, color, national origin, sex or religious creed and with proper regard for their privacy and constitutional
rights as citizens.
(6)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
53/489
Assuring that employees are protected against coercion for partisan political purposes and are prohibited from using their
official authority for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the result of an election or a nomination for office as
stipulated in this article.
(Ord. No. 0-84-10, Art. I, 3-20-84)
Sec. 2-163. - Coverage.
All offices and positions of the city shall be and are hereby allocated to the career or exempt service. The career service
shall be a permanent service to which this article shall apply and shall include tenured positions in the city now existing or
hereafter established, except the following:
(1)
The members of the commission and other elected positions.
(2)
Members of boards and commissions, judges and heads of divisions appointed by the city manager.
(3)
Persons employed to make or conduct a temporary or special inquiry, investigation, or examination on behalf of the city
commission, a committee thereof, or the city manager.
(4)
Temporary or part-time positions unless specifically covered by action of the city commission or the city manager.
(Ord. No. 0-84-10, Art. II, 3-20-84)
Sec. 2-164. - General administration responsibility.
The city manager shall have the responsibility for the personnel program as set forth in this article. The city manager shall:
(1)
Be responsible for effective personnel administration.
(2)
Appoint, remove, suspend and discipline all officers and employees subject to the policies set forth in the article and local
personnel policies adopted hereunder; or it may, at his discretion, authorize the division head or the head of the department
or office to appoint and remove employees of such divisions, departments and offices.
(3)
Fix and establish the number of employees in various city divisions, departments and offices and determine the duties and
compensation in accordance with policies set forth in local ordinance and subject to budget limitations.
(4)
Perform such other duties and exercise such other powers in personnel administration as may be prescribed by law, this
article and legal directions of the city commission.
(Ord. No. 0-84-10, Art. III(A), 3-20-84)
Sec. 2-165. - Personnel officer.
The city manager shall have the authority to appoint a personnel officer, or if a full-time personnel officer cannot be
justified, may delegate the duties enumerated herein to an employee under his jurisdiction, who shall be responsible for the
administration and technical direction of the local government personnel program. The personnel officer shall be known by
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
54/489
the job title designated by the city manager. The personnel officer may have other staff members designated to assist him or
may designate any member of his staff to assist him. His duties shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
(1)
Encourage and exercise leadership in the development of effective personnel administration practices within the city.
(2)
Advise the city manager on matters affecting the most effective use of manpower resources.
(3)
Foster and develop programs for the improvement of employee effectiveness, including training, safety, health, counseling
and welfare.
(4)
Investigate from time to time the operation and effect of this law and of the policies made hereunder and report his findings
and recommendations to the city manager.
(5)
Establish and maintain personnel records for each employee in the government service including his position title, pay
grade and step, date of employment and other relevant data.
(6)
Make an annual report to the city manager regarding the status of the personnel administration program.
(7)
Apply and carry out this article and the policies hereunder and perform any other lawful acts which may be necessary or
desirable to carry out the purposes and provisions of this article or other related personnel duties.
(Ord. No. 0-84-10, Art. III(B), 3-20-84)
Sec. 2-166. - Personnel policies.
(a)
Adopted by reference herewith as a part hereof are the personnel policies, organization plan and pay plan. Official copies of
the personnel policies, organization plan and pay plan are on file in the city clerk's office where they are available for
inspection and review. The personnel officer shall draft or cause to be drafted, when appropriate, amendments to existing
personnel policies, rules and regulations for consideration of the city commission. Adequate public notice of proposed
personnel policies additions or changes shall be given to all interested parties prior to the time they are to take effect. If
requested by any of the affected parties, the personnel officer shall schedule a public hearing on such proposed personnel
policies. The proposed policies shall then be submitted for adoption by resolution of the city commission. The policies
heretofore adopted shall have the force and effect of law, and may be amended in accordance with the above procedure.
(b)
The policies shall be reviewed periodically to constantly provide for:
(1)
The revision of a position classification plan for all positions in the career service, based upon similarity of duties
performed and responsibilities assumed, so that the same qualifications may reasonably be required for, and the schedule of
pay may be equitably applied to all positions in the same class.
(2)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
55/489
The announcement of vacancies and the acceptance of applications for employment.
(3)
Preparation and administration of examinations and/or evaluations.
(4)
Establishment and use of employment lists containing names of persons eligible for employment.
(5)
Transfer, promotion and reinstatement of employees.
(6)
Performance evaluations of employees, including those serving a probationary period.
(7)
Separation from the service of employees by resignation, layoff, suspension, dismissal and for incapacity to perform
required duties.
(8)
Development of employee morale, safety and training programs.
(9)
Maintenance and use of necessary employee records and personnel forms.
(10)
Such other matters as may be necessary and proper to carry out the intent and purpose of this article.
(c)
The personnel officer or his authorized agent shall be responsible for the certification of the payroll vouchers that the
persons named therein have been appointed and employed in accordance with the provisions of this article and the policies
hereunder. The city disbursing or auditing officer shall not make or approve any payment for personal service to any person
holding a position in the city unless such payroll voucher or account of such pay bears the certification of the division head
and the personnel officer or his authorized agent.
(Ord. No. 0-84-10, Art. III(C), 3-20-84)
Sec. 2-167. - Grievance procedures.
(a)
A grievance is any dispute concerning the interpretation or application of this article, or of the personnel policies governing
personnel practices or working conditions, or decision relative to any disciplinary action, dismissal, demotion or charge of
discrimination.
(b)
Grievances shall be processed in accordance with procedures established by the city commission in the personnel policies.
(Ord. No. 0-84-10, Art. IV, 3-20-84)
Sec. 2-168. - Agreements authorized.
(a)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
56/489
The city commission is authorized and empowered to enter into reciprocal agreements, upon such terms as may be agreed
upon, for the use of equipment, materials, facilities and services with any public agency or body for purposes deemed of
benefit to the public personnel system.
(b)
The personnel officer, acting in behalf of the city commission may cooperate with other governmental agencies charged
with public personnel administration in conducting personnel tests, recruiting personnel, training personnel, establishing
lists from which eligibles shall be certified for appointment and for the interchange of personnel and their benefits.
(Ord. No. 0-84-10, Art. V, 3-20-84)
Sec. 2-169. - Political activities.
(a)
No city employee in the career service shall offer for or hold elective office in the city, county, state or national
government; nor shall he give or solicit any contributions or assessments, or publicly endorse any candidate for any city
elective officer.
(b)
Nothing herein contained shall affect the right of an employee to contribute to, hold membership in, serve as an officer, or
support a political party, to vote as he chooses, to support or campaign for political candidates of other governmental
jurisdictions, to express privately his opinions on all political subjects and candidates, to maintain political neutrality or to
attend political meetings.
(c)
Any city employee who, as a normal and foreseeable incident to his principal job or position, performs duties in connection
with an activity financed in whole or in part by federal loans or grants, comes under the Federal Hatch Act which prohibits
the following:
(1)
Use of official authority or influence for the purpose of interfering with an election or nomination for office, or affecting the
results thereof.
(2)
Directly or indirectly coercing, attempting to coerce, commanding or advising any other such officer or employee to pay,
lend, or contribute any part of his salary or compensation or anything else of value to any party, committee, organization,
agency or person for political purposes.
(3)
Active participation in political management or in political campaigns.
(Ord. No. 0-84-10, Art. VI, 3-20-84)
Sec. 2-170. - Unlawful acts prohibited.
(a)
No person shall make any false statements, certificate, mark or report with regard to any test, certification or appointment
made under any provision of this article or in any matter commit or attempt to commit any fraud preventing the impartial
execution of this article and policies.
(b)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
57/489
No person, shall directly or indirectly, give, render, pay, offer, solicit or accept any money, service or other valuable
consideration for any appointment, proposed appointment, promotion or proposed promotion to, or any advantage in, a
position in the career service.
(c)
No employee of the personnel department, examiner or other person shall defeat, deceive or obstruct any person in his right
to examination, eligibility, certification or appointment under this article, or furnish to any person any special or secret
information for the purpose of affecting the rights or prospects of any person with respect to employment in the career
service.
(Ord. No. 0-84-10, Art. VII, 3-20-84)
Sec. 2-171. - Penalties.
Any person who willfully violates any provision of this article or of the personnel policies established hereunder may, upon
action of the proper authority as outlined in the personnel policies, have one (1) of the following judgments rendered:
(1)
Dismissal from government service.
(2)
Demotion in rank or grade.
(3)
Suspension for a period of time not to exceed thirty (30) days.
(4)
Ineligibility for appointment to or employment in a position in the government service for a period of time or indefinitely.
(Ord. No. 0-84-10, Art. VIII, 3-20-84)
Sec. 2-172. - Status of present employees.
Employees holding positions in the career service herein for six (6) months or more immediately prior to the adoption of
the ordinance from which this section derives shall be continued in their respective positions without further examination,
until separated from their positions as provided by law. Those holding positions for less than six (6) months immediately
prior to the adoption of this article shall serve a probationary period as prescribed by the personnel policies. Those who
shall have failed to qualify as provided herein shall be dismissed from their positions within thirty (30) days after
establishment of an eligible list for their respective positions. Nothing herein shall preclude the reclassification or
reallocation as provided by this article of any position held by any incumbent.
(Ord. No. 0-84-10, Art. IX, 3-20-84)
Secs. 2-173—2-190. - Reserved.
ARTICLE VIII. - PLANNING COMMISSION
FOOTNOTE(S):

State Law reference— Authority to adopt plans and exercise the power of zoning, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 4; The
Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; local government zoning powers, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-2; conflicts of
interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.; coordinated and comprehensive planning by counties and
municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.; effect of zoning laws on covenants running with the land, O.C.G.A. § 44-5-60.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
58/489
Sec. 2-191. - Membership.
(a)
The planning commission shall consist of five (5) members who shall be residents of the city or own real property in the
city. Appointments to the planning commission shall be made by the city commission for terms of five (5) years, except
that in the organization of the 1991 planning commission the terms of the three (3) city-appointed members of the previous
city-county planning commission shall be preserved, with one (1) of the new 1991 appointments being for a term of one (1)
year.
(b)
Any variety in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the city commission which shall have the authority to
remove any member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing before the city commission.
(Code 1977, § 2-9; Ord. No. 0-90-34, § A, 12-18-90)
Sec. 2-192. - Organization; rules; staff; finances.
The planning commission shall elect its chairman from among its members. The chairman shall have all rights as a
member, including but not limited to the right to vote and introduce motions. The term of the chairman shall be one (1)
year with eligibility for reelection. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or employee
of the city. The planning commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine the times of its meetings, which
shall be open to the public. Records of the meetings shall be public records. The planning commission may appoint such
employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its functions and may contract with the state planning commission and
with city planners and other consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditures of the planning commission,
exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts for designated purposes by the city commission.
(Code 1977, § 2-10; Ord. No. 0-90-34, § A, 12-18-90)
Sec. 2-193. - Powers and duties.
From and after the time at which the planning commission shall have convened for its first 1991 meeting, selected its
officers, and adopted its rules of procedure, it shall have all the powers, duties, and responsibilities set forth in this Code,
ordinances of the city, "The Zoning Procedures (O.C.G.A. §§ 36-66-1 through 36-66-5) as the same may be hereafter
amended, and Chapter 67A of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated (O.C.G.A. §§ 36-67A-1 through 36-67A-4) as the
same may be hereafter amended.
(Ord. No. 0-90-34, § A, 12-18-90)
Secs. 2-194—2-210. - Reserved.

ARTICLE X. - UNCLAIMED PROPERTY IN POSSESSION OF POLICE DEPARTMENT
Sec. 2-231. - Disposal authorized.
All personal property coming into the possession of the police department from any source, wherein the owner is unknown
or wherein the owner cannot be located, wherein the item is not contraband and has no foreseeable evidentiary value, with
the exception of motor vehicles, firearms and bicycles, which are covered elsewhere within this article, shall be disposed of
as provided in this article.
(Ord. No. 0-85-3, § 15-1(a), 2-5-85)
Sec. 2-232. - Attempt to locate owner.
Every effort shall be made to locate the rightful owner of unclaimed property coming under the provisions of this article.
(Ord. No. 0-85-3, § 15-1(a)(1), 2-5-85)
Sec. 2-233. - Retention following use as evidence.
If any property coming under this article is evidence in any proceeding, it shall be retained for sixty (60) days from the date
of final termination of such proceeding.
(Ord. No. 0-85-3, § 15-1(a)(1)a., 2-5-85)
Sec. 2-234. - Public notice of pending disposition.
A notice shall be placed for five (5) consecutive days in the legal organ of the county specifically describing each item of
property coming under this article and advising the possible owners of items of the method of contacting the police
department. Such notice shall also stipulate a date, time and place such items will be placed for public sale if not claimed,
or converted to use by the city. Such notice shall also stipulate whether such items or groups of items are to be sold in
blocks, by lot numbers, by entire list of items or separately.
(Ord. No. 0-85-3, § 15-1(a)(1)b., 2-5-85)
Sec. 2-235. - Conversion to use by the city.
Upon written request of the head of a department of the city, submitted to the city commission and with approval by the
city commission, advertised items not claimed by the owner may be converted to use by the department making the
request.
(Ord. No. 0-85-3, § 15-1(a)(1)c., 2-5-85)
Sec. 2-236. - Public sale.
Items of property coming under this article not claimed by the owners or not converted to city use shall be sold at a sale
which shall be conducted not less than fifteen (15) nor more than sixty (60) days after the advertised notice has been run.
The sale shall be to the highest bidder for cash.
(Ord. No. 0-85-3, § 15-1(a)(1)d., 2-5-85)
Sec. 2-237. - Salvage disposal.
If property offered for sale under this article has not been bid on in two (2) successive sales, it will be considered as salvage
and disposed of as other city salvage or nonserviceable equipment is disposed of.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
60/489
(Ord. No. 0-85-3, § 15-1(a)(1)e., 2-5-85)
Sec. 2-238. - Records.
Records will be maintained showing the manner in which each item came into possession of the police department, a
description of the property, all efforts to locate the owner, any case or docket number, the date of publication of any
newspaper notices, and the date of sale.
(Ord. No. 0-85-3, § 15-1, 2-5-85)
Sec. 2-239. - Bicycles.
(a)
Bicycles which may come into possession of the police department as a result of being abandoned or stolen shall be kept
for a period of sixty (60) days, and every reasonable effort will be made to determine the owner thereof. If, after sixty (60)
days, it cannot be determined who the bicycle rightfully belongs to and there has been no claim for such bicycle, the
bicycle may be donated to any nonprofit organization or group making a request for such to the chief of police, upon the
consent of the city commission.
(b)
Records shall be kept on such bicycles as to when and how acquired, and when and to whom disposition was made, and
proper receipts shall be obtained by the police department.
(Ord. No. 0-85-3, § 15-1(b), 2-5-85)
Sec. 2-240. - Firearms and dangerous weapons.
Firearms and dangerous weapons which come into the possession of the police department will be disposed of as follows:
(1)
Firearms which are received for safekeeping or which are received as found property and for which the owner is unknown
at the time received may be returned to the owner upon showing of proper proof of ownership. Items which are not claimed
by the owner within ninety (90) days shall be disposed of as provided for in subsection (4) of this section.
(2)
Firearms which are placed in evidence as evidence of a crime will be kept until they have no foreseeable evidentiary value.
At that time, if the owner of the firearm is known and upon direction of the chief of police, the firearm may be returned to
the owner upon showing of proper proof of ownership unless the firearm was used by the owner in the commission of a
crime, in which case the firearm will not be returned to the owner except upon receipt of a court order. Firearms which are
not claimed by the owner within ninety (90) days shall be disposed of as provided for in subsection (4) of this section.
(3)
Dangerous weapons other than firearms which were received as recovered or found property and which have no
foreseeable evidentiary value may be returned to the owner, except for contraband items or items which would be illegal
for a citizen to possess. Dangerous weapons which were used by the owner in the commission of a crime will not be
returned to the owner. Items not claimed by the owner within ninety (90) days and items not returnable to the owner will be
destroyed as provided for in subsection (4) of this section.
(4)
The procedure for disposal of firearms and other dangerous weapons which are unclaimed shall be in accordance with the
following:
a.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
61/489
Public notice of pending disposition; time limitations for disposal. An effort will be made, by certified mail, to notify the
known owner of all firearms and dangerous weapons, except those excluded by this subsection or other state or federal
laws, or by having a notice placed for five (5) successive days in a newspaper, if the owner is unknown, specifically
describing each item and advising possible owners of the items of the method of contacting the police department. The
advertised firearms will not be disposed of less than fifteen (15) days or more than thirty (30) days after the last advertising
notice has run.
b.
Conversion to use by the city. Advertised firearms not claimed by the owner, firearms not returned to the owner because of
the operation of this subsection or any other state or federal law, and any other dangerous weapon not returnable to the
owner may be converted over to use by the police department upon a written request being submitted to the city
commission and upon approval of the request by the city commission. A record will be maintained of each weapon or other
dangerous weapons which have been converted over to city use and will include a complete description of each item and
the use to which each is to be put. The items will also be included on the property books of the department which has
custody of the item.
c.
Destruction. Any firearms or dangerous weapons which are not converted over to city use as provided for in this subsection
will be disposed of by having the items melted down until they no longer are of value or use as a weapon. Records will be
maintained showing a complete description of each item destroyed and will be signed by at least two (2) witnesses to their
destruction.
(Ord. No. 0-85-3, § 15-1(c), 2-5-85)
Sec. 2-241. - Trading of firearms and other dangerous weapons permitted.
The city and the police department may trade firearms and other dangerous weapons to any legally authorized weapons
dealer in return for credit to the city, or for allowance as trade-in on the purchase of firearms and other dangerous weapons
for use by the police department.
(Ord. No. 0-85-3, § 15-1(e), 2-5-85)
Sec. 2-242. - Contraband items.
Contraband items which have no foreseeable evidentiary value will be disposed of by the police department in such a
manner that will insure that the items are no longer of value and cannot be recovered by anyone, or the items will be turned
over to the proper county, state or federal agency for disposition. A record will be maintained of the items which have been
destroyed.
(Ord. No. 0-85-3, § 15-1(d), 2-5-85)
Secs. 2-243—2-265. - Reserved.

(a)
The block grant ordinance set forth in the 1977 Code as sections 7.5-16 through 7.5-22 are not repealed and shall continue
in full force and effect pending a revision of the subject matter by the city.
(b)
An official copy of the ordinance described in subsection (a) is on file in the city clerk's office.
