DIVISION 2. - EXCISE TAX
Sec. 3-41. - Definitions.
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them:
Malt beverages means any fermented beverage made in whole or in part from malt or any similar fermented beverage.
Retail malt beverages dealer means any person who engages in selling malt beverages at retail within the city and shall
include any person serving malt beverages for a pecuniary consideration within the corporate limits of the city.
Wholesale malt beverages dealer means any person who sells malt beverages to a retail malt beverages dealer.
(Code 1977, § 3-30)
Sec. 3-42. - Tax levied.
There is hereby imposed and levied a specific excise tax upon all malt beverages dealers within the city, as follows:
(1)
Five cents ($0.05) per twelve (12) ounces or fractional part thereof, regardless of container size.
(2)
Six dollars ($6.00) per container of fifteen and one-half (15½) gallons, or fractional part thereof, of tap or draft malt
beverages.
(Code 1977, § 3-31)
Sec. 3-43. - Possession of specified number of bottles, presumption of business.
Any person having located in his place of business more than twenty-four (24) bottles of malt beverages at any one (1)
time, shall be presumed as a matter of law to be in the business of selling malt beverages for a pecuniary consideration.
(Code 1977, § 3-32)
Sec. 3-44. - Additional to other taxes and licenses; payment and collection procedure.
The taxes imposed and levied by this division shall be in addition to all other taxes or licenses or license fees levied or
imposed upon malt beverage dealers, and it may be added by the retail malt beverages dealer to the retail price and
collected by him from each customer.
(Code 1977, § 3-33)
State law reference— Levy and amount of excise tax on malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80.
Secs. 3-45—3-60. - Reserved.
ARTICLE III. - WINE
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
72/489
Sec. 3-61. - Sale in package store only; exception; license for food service establishments.
Retail sales of wine shall be made in the city in retail package stores duly licensed by the city for the sale of distilled
spirits, provided that a separate retail license for the sale of wine in the city may be purchased from the city by a licensed
restaurant, hotel, motel or other business engaged in selling food to the public for consumption upon the premises where
sold, when each of the following conditions are complied with:
(1)
Application for a separate retail wine license for the sale of wine shall be made in writing to city commission, setting forth
the same information required for application for retail license for the sale of distilled spirits. Any application for a separate
retail wine license under this section acknowledges by such application that such license is a privilege and not a right.
(2)
The fee for a separate retail wine license shall be as determined by the city commission from time to time and listed in the
schedule of fees and charges maintained in the city clerk's office, which amount shall accompany the application, and the
pro-rata credit for a partial year's operation shall be as provided by sections of this chapter regulating the sale of distilled
spirits; provided however, that renewals of such license shall not require formal application, but shall be as provided by
sections of this chapter regulating the sale of distilled spirits, as the same provides for renewals of licenses.
(3)
An establishment licensed under a separate retail wine license shall be subject to the same tax per case of wine purchased
as is provided by section 3-62
(4)
An establishment licensed under a separate retail wine license is hereby expressly authorized to sell wine by the bottle
and/or by the glass to retail customers upon the premises to be consumed with food, and any other sale of wine hereunder,
other than with food, is expressly prohibited.
(Code 1977, § 3-40)
Sec. 3-62. - Tax on cases purchased by retail package store.
Any duly licensed retail package store in the city shall also have the right and privilege to sell wine without any additional
license fee, except that there shall be a specific tax in the amount of two dollars and forty cents ($2.40) on each case of
wine purchased by a retail package store.
(Code 1977, § 3-41)
Sec. 3-63. - License required for wholesaler.
There is hereby levied, assessed and required a license fee in an amount as determined by the city commission from time to
time and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained in the city clerk's office for any person to engage in the
wholesale sale of wine in the city.
(Code 1977, § 3-42)
Sec. 3-64. - Retailers subject to laws, regulations governing sale of spirits.
All retail sales of wine shall be subject to the ordinances, rules and regulations of the city applicable to the retail sale of
distilled spirits.
(Code 1977, § 3-44)
Secs. 3-65—3-80. - Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. - DISTILLED SPIRITS
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
73/489
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) ---
State Law reference— Authority for municipality or county to adopt rules and regulations relating to manufacture, sale
and distribution of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-49.
Sec. 3-81. - License required.
There is hereby levied, assessed and required an annual license for any person to engage in the sale of distilled spirits in the
city. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the sale of distilled spirits without first registering and paying such
license.
(Code 1977, § 3-50)
Sec. 3-82. - Application for license—Contents.
(a)
The person desiring a license under this article shall first make written application to the city commission setting forth the
following information:
(1)
The name of the applicant and if a firm the names of all the members thereof, and if a corporation the names of all the
directors, officers and stockholders thereof.
(2)
Whether any other person is to be interested directly or indirectly in the proposed business and if the interested party is a
person, the name of such person, and if the interested party is a firm, the names of all the members thereof, and if the
interested party is a corporation, the names of all the directors, officers and stockholders thereof.
(3)
The location of the proposed business giving the name of the street and the street number.
(4)
The length of residence of the applicant in the city and/or in the county or members of the firm or directors, officers and
stockholders of the corporation.
(5)
Any additional information that the city commission may request of the person applying for the license.
(b)
The making of any untrue or misleading statement in the application for a license hereunder shall be sufficient cause for the
denial, suspension, revocation, or cancellation of such license by the city commission without refund of any part of the
license fee.
(c)
Application for renewal of the license shall be executed in the same manner as the application for the original license.
(Code 1977, § 3-51)
Sec. 3-83. - Same—Forms; submitting fee; refund.
All applications and notices provided for in this article shall be made on forms provided by the city. Application for a
license shall be accompanied either in lawful money of the United States, certified check, or cashiers check payable to the
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
74/489
city for the proper amount of the license fee. In the event that the applicant is refused a license by the revenue
commissioner of the state, the license fee shall be returned to the applicant. The provisions of this section do not apply to
suspension or revocation of a license by the city commission or the revenue commissioner of the state, or by any agency of
the United States of America or by any court.
(Code 1977, § 3-52)
Sec. 3-84. - Excise tax.
(a)
There is hereby levied on all sales of distilled spirits excluding fortified wine, an excise tax of twenty-two cents ($0.22) per
liter gallon.
(b)
This tax is in addition to all other licenses or taxes imposed by the city.
(Code 1977, § 3-53)
Sec. 3-85. - License period; credit for fee on partial year; no proration; transferability.
(a)
The license or privilege to sell distilled spirits shall be issued or granted for a period no longer than twelve (12) months.
The license shall expire on December thirty-first of the year in which it is granted. However, any person having paid the
full year's license fee shall be entitled to a credit on his next year's license in an amount representing the unused portion of
his license for the initial year of purchase. In calculating the unused portion of such license, credit shall be allowed by
quarters so that any person commencing business between January first and April first shall not be allowed any credit on
his next year's license, any person commencing business after April first and before July first shall be allowed credit on his
next year's license for one (1) quarter, any person commencing business on or after July first and before October first shall
be allowed credit on his next year's license for one-half. Any person commencing business on or after October first and
before December first shall be allowed credit of three-fourths on his next year's license. The credit so calculated shall not
be transferable or payable except in a license granted for the next succeeding year, and in order to get credit for the unused
portion of his license the person must apply and pay for his license before February first of the next succeeding year.
(b)
No license shall be prorated for any part of the year.
(c)
No license shall be transferable from one (1) licensee to another person.
(Code 1977, § 3-54)
Sec. 3-86. - Wholesaler's invoices.
Any wholesale dealer who sells to retail package stores in the city shall file a copy of each invoice with the city clerk. This
invoice shall be identical with the one furnished to the United States Internal Revenue Service.
(Code 1977, § 3-55)
Sec. 3-87. - Additional remedy in default in payment of sums due.
In the event of default in the payment of any amount due under the provisions of this article on the part of any person, the
collection of the same shall, in addition to other penalties, be enforced and executed as for city taxes.
(Code 1977, § 3-56)
Sec. 3-88. - Payment of delinquent sums due city prerequisite to issuance of license.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
75/489
In addition to the licenses herein imposed, there is further imposed as a condition precedent to the issuance of any license
under this article, the payment of all past due licenses, ad valorem taxes and other taxes due to the city.
(Code 1977, § 3-57)
Sec. 3-89. - Private club license.
Upon the payment of a fee as determined by the city commission from time to time and listed in the schedule of fees and
charges maintained in the city clerk's office, any club, patriotic organization, charitable organization, or fraternal
organization which has been in operation in the city for a continuous period of five (5) years immediately prior to
application for a license under this article, under a national charter, and which is nonprofit in that the individual members
do not receive any dividends or share in the profits shall be licensed to make retail sales provided retail sales shall be made
on the premises at its principal location to its members only.
(Code 1977, § 3-58)
State law reference— Authority of counties or municipalities to regulate and license private clubs generally, O.C.G.A. §
3-7-40.
Sec. 3-90. - Other laws and regulations applicable; revocation of license for violation.
Every licensee shall strictly comply with the laws and regulations of the United States of America, the state and the state
revenue commission which regulate and control distilled spirits. In the event that any licensee is convicted of violating any
federal or state law relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages, such license is automatically revoked and no part of the
license money shall be refunded.
(Code 1977, § 3-59)
Sec. 3-91. - Change of licensee's location.
The location named in the licensee's application shall not be changed without permission of and approval of the city
commission.
(Code 1977, § 3-60)
Sec. 3-92. - Sale declared privilege, not right; privilege denied to convicted felon.
No person who has been convicted of a felony under federal laws or the laws of any state shall be granted a license to sell
distilled spirits.
(Code 1977, § 3-61)
Sec. 3-93. - Zoning requirements; exceptions.
No license for the sale of spirituous liquors or distilled spirits shall be granted for a business location in any district
designated as R-1 residential, R-2 residential, R-12, R-7.5S, R-7.5, H-1, PEH, PW or M-1 industrial under The 1999
Zoning Ordinance for the City of Cordele, effective date of May 1, 1999. Private clubs, patriotic organizations, or fraternal
organizations meeting all the requirements of section 3-89 are excepted if in compliance with such zoning regulations.
(Code 1977, § 3-62; Ord. No. 0-04-03, 2-23-04)
Sec. 3-94. - Stock to be kept on premises; only one entrance permitted; premises to be open to view.
All distilled spirits possessed by a licensee shall be kept in the package store. No retailer's place of business shall have
more than one (1) entrance which must open on a public street and such place of business shall have no other entrance and
shall contain no vestibule, closet, booth, or other place where persons may conceal themselves to consume alcoholic
beverages.
(Code 1977, § 3-65)
Sec. 3-95. - Access to other establishments prohibited; windows to face on same street as entrance.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
76/489
No package store shall be operated in conjunction with or open into or have access to or from any restaurant, lunch room,
dining room, dance hall or other store or business of any kind or character. The windows in every package store shall face
the same public street faced by the entrance to the package store and such windows shall not be obstructed or obscured in
any manner, except as provided in section 3-97.
(Code 1977, § 3-66)
Sec. 3-96. - Obstructing windows.
No place of business operating under this article shall display on the exterior thereof any neon or fluorescent signs to
advertise either the name or the products of the store. Any interior sign shall be confined to the upper part of the window so
as not to obstruct the view of the interior of the package store.
(Code 1977, § 3-67)
Sec. 3-97. - Persons under twenty-one years of age prohibited on premises.
No person under twenty-one (21) years of age shall be permitted to enter a retail package store, and each licensee shall be
held strictly responsible for the enforcement of this section.
(Code 1977, § 3-68; Ord. No. 0-91-16, § 5, 5-8-91)
Secs. 3-98, 3-99. - Reserved.
ARTICLE V. - LIQUOR BY THE DRINK
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 3-100. - Purposes.
(a)
The purposes of this article shall include, without necessarily being limited to, the following:
(1)
Compliance with and effectuation of the general state law;
(2)
Prevention and control of the sale of alcoholic beverages by unfit persons;
(3)
Insuring that any licenses issued for the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises are issued only to a legitimate
restaurant or private club as defined in this article;
(4)
The protection of schools, homes, churches, parks, and other institutions;
(5)
Protection of the public health, safety, and welfare.
(b)
To the maximum extent permissible under state and federal law, the business of selling alcoholic beverages shall under this
article be considered to be a privilege to be accorded in conformity with the foregoing and other public policies of the city,
rather than a right.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-101. - Definitions.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
77/489
(a)
Unless a contrary intention is clearly apparent from the context, the following terms used in this article shall have the
following meaning:
Alcoholic beverage means and includes all alcohol, malt beverages, distilled spirits, wine and fortified wines defined in this
section.
City means the City of Cordele and when used in a geographical sense means the territorial limits of the City of Cordele.
City clerk means the city clerk of the City of Cordele.
City commission means the city commission of the City of Cordele.
Distilled spirits means any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation.
Interest includes any pecuniary interest and any ownership interest, whether present or future, whole or partial, legal or
beneficial, contingent or vested, direct or indirect, and any right, power, or authority of control.
Licensed premises includes not only the room wherein alcoholic beverages are sold or served but also the entire building in
which such room is located, except that when such a room is located in a hotel, motel, or similar facility or in a shopping
center only such room and any adjoining storage, office, toilet, and other similar rooms shall constitute the "licensed
premises."
Licensee includes an individual licensee and in the case of a partnership or corporation includes both the partnership or
corporation and the named licensee.
Majority stockholder means the person, if any, who owns more than fifty (50) percent of the voting stock of a corporation;
if no person owns more than fifty (50) percent of the voting of a corporation, the "majority stockholder" is the person
owning more of the voting stock than any other person; and if two (2) or more persons each own the same amount of the
voting stock of a corporation and each own more of the voting stock than any other person, then any one (1) of such
persons may act as the "majority stockholder."
Mixed drink or liquor by the drink means any distilled spirits served for consumption on the premises, whether or not
diluted by water or any other substance.
Named licensee means the person acting as such for a partnership or corporation pursuant to section.
Person includes a corporation, partnership, association, club or institution.
Semipublic parking facility means any privately owned area wherein motor vehicles may be parked by the public in
conjunction with any business, enterprise, commercial establishment, office building, church, school, or multiple-family
residential building.
(b)
Unless a contrary intention is clearly apparent from the context, any term used in this article shall have the same meaning
as when used in comparable provision of the Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. title 3.
(c)
As used in this article, the singular and plural shall each include the other, the masculine and feminine shall include each
other, and any verb tense may include the other verb tense.
(d)
As used in this article, the term "may" is permissive and the term "shall" is mandatory.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-102. - Violations; penalty.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
78/489
(a)
Any person who violates any provision of this article shall upon conviction in the Cordele Municipal Court be punished as
provided in this Code, which may include a fine or imprisonment, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Any such
punishment, if imposed, shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any license suspension or revocation under this article.
(b)
The violation of any of the provisions of this article, including the maximum occupant load, shall be grounds for fines,
suspension, or revocation of any license issued hereunder.
(1)
For the first violation there shall be a one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) fine.
(2)
For the second violation, the date of occurrence of which is within any 24-month period of the first violation, there shall be
a one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) fine and a thirty-day suspension of the license privileges.
(3)
For the third, and any subsequent violation, the date of occurrence of which is within any twenty-four-month period of the
first violation, there shall be a one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) fine and a ninety-day suspension of license privileges.
(4)
For any violation beyond the third, the date of occurrence of which is within any twenty-four-month period of the first
violation, the license may be revoked at the discretion of the city commission.
(5)
Any suspension, or revocation of a license shall first require notice to the license holder of a due process hearing before the
city commission, as required by section 3-129 herein.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06; Ord. No. 0-06-08, § 1, 5-16-06)
Sec. 3-103. - City manager's duties.
(a)
The city manager, or the city manager's designee, are hereby vested with the following duties and powers:
(1)
To take all applications, to screen, verify, investigate and review all initial applications for licenses for the sale of liquor by
the drink.
(2)
To recommend to the city commission modifications to the ordinances and policies of the city pertaining to the regulation
control and taxing of liquor by the drink.
(3)
To hear complaints, suggestions and recommendations from the, public safety department, state officials, alcoholic
beverage providers, and the public at large as to the operation of liquor by the drink outlets within the city.
(b)
After screening, investigating and complying with all parts of this article, the city manager or the city manager's designee,
with the approval of the city commission, shall grant the applicant's desired license or shall deny said license, applying all
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
79/489
requirements of this article.
(c)
An applicant, or any city or state official objecting to the request of the applicant, who is dissatisfied with the decision, may
appeal the aggrieved action to the city commission, whose decision on the appeal shall be final. Any appeal from the
decision must be filed within thirty (30) days, and the chairman of the city commission will schedule the appeal for a
hearing within thirty (30) days.
(d)
All renewal decisions shall be made by the city manager or the city manager's designee employing the rules and regulations
of this article.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Secs. 3-104—3-120. - Reserved.
DIVISION 2. - LICENSING
Sec. 3-121. - Required classifications, etc.
(a)
Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any liquor by the drink within the city except under a
valid license issued under this article and in compliance with the provisions of this article.
(b)
Pay schedule. License fees shall be payable in advance for an entire year beginning January 1 and ending December 31 of
each year. If an initial fee is paid on or before June 30 of the year of application, the license fees shall not be prorated for a
part of year. If an initial fee is paid after June 30 but on the year of application, the license fee shall be reduced fifty (50)
percent. The suspension or revocation of any license granted pursuant to this article shall not entitle the licensee to a return
of any portion of the license fee.
(c)
Classification fee. Class of license issued under this article, activities permitted and regulated hereunder, and the annual
license fee shall be as follows:
Liquor by the drink license .....$2,500.00
(For consumption on the premises)
(d)
Application fees. Each application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee
in the amount of one thousand two hundred fifty dollars ($1,250.00).
(e)
Payment of fees. Application fees shall be paid at the time the application is filed and shall not be refunded under any
circumstances. An applicant may pay the annual license fee at the time the application is filed; and in such event the annual
license fee shall be refunded if the license applied for is not issued. If the annual license fee is not paid at the time of the
application, the annual license fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of the license by the city manager or the city
manager's designee, and no later than fourteen (14) days after notification of approval. Failure to pay within fourteen (14)
days shall bear a ten (10) percent penalty on the license fee and a one (1) percent interest rate monthly until paid in full.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06; Ord. No. 0-06-08, § 2, 5-16-06)
Sec. 3-122. - Procedure for issuance.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
80/489
(a)
A license issued to an individual shall be issued in the name of the individual. A license issued to a partnership shall be
issued in the name of the partnership and in the name of one (1) of the partners who shall be the named licensee. A license
issued to a corporation having as its business the sale of liquor by the drink shall be issued in the name of the corporation
and in the name of the majority stockholder or a principal officer of the corporation; and such majority stockholder or
officer shall be the named licensee. A license issued to a corporation having as its business an activity other than the sale of
liquor by the drink shall be issued in the name of the corporation and in the name of the officer or employee of the
corporation primarily responsible for the operation of the licensed premises; and such officer or employee shall be the
named licensee.
(b)
In the case of a partnership, each partner shall join as an applicant for the license and each partner must meet the
qualifications of an individual licensee, as provided herein.
(c)
In the case of a corporation having as its business the sale of liquor by the drink, the majority stockholder and each
principal officer of the corporation shall join as applicants for the license; and each such person must meet the
qualifications of an individual licensee.
(d)
In the case of a corporation having as its principal business an activity other than the sale of liquor by the drink, the officer
or employee who is to be the named licensee shall be the applicant and must meet the qualifications of an individual
licensee, as provided herein; provided, however, that the city manager or the city manager's designee, with the approval of
the city commission, may require the fingerprinting and investigation of officers and shareholders of the corporation if they
deem it necessary in making their investigation.
(e)
In the case of a partnership, each partner shall be responsible for the actions of the named licensee and the conduct of the
licensed business. In the case of a corporation, the corporation shall be responsible for the actions of the named licensee
and the conduct of the licensed business.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-123. - Qualifications.
(a)
A licensee must be at least twenty-one (21) years of age, of good moral character and a citizen of the United States.
(b)
A licensee shall not have been convicted within the past five (5) years of any felony or, misdemeanor, or violation of city
alcohol ordinances within the past two (2) years, or at any time of any criminal offense relating to alcoholic beverages,
drugs, taxes or gambling. This subsection shall apply with respect to the laws of this state, other states, the United States,
and other countries. A plea of nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond shall be considered a conviction for purposes of
this subsection. The city commission may at its discretion waive the conviction of a misdemeanor for a non-alcoholic
offense for purposes of this subsection if the city commission determines that the misdemeanor does not have a bearing on
the applicant's fitness for a license.
(c)
A licensee shall not have been denied or had revoked, within the five (5) years next preceding his application, any license
to sell alcoholic beverages issued by any governmental entity.
(d)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
81/489
No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises shall be issued to any applicant
who does not meet the requirements of a private club or restaurant as defined in sections 3-161 and 3-160
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-124. - Application procedures.
(a)
Application for a license for the sale of liquor by the drink in the city shall be filed with the city clerk upon forms
prescribed by the city clerk and made available at city hall. The application shall be subscribed by the applicant under oath
and fully completed and executed. The city clerk shall deliver the application to the city manager or the city manager's
designee.
(b)
There shall be attached to the application a bank money order, certified check or like remittance of the application.
(c)
As a prerequisite to the issuance of the license, the applicant shall furnish a complete set of fingerprints to be forwarded to
the state bureau of investigation which shall search the files and forward the fingerprints to the Georgia Bureau of
Investigation to determine past criminal activity.
(d)
Failure to fully complete and execute an application for a license or to furnish accurately all data, information and records
required by the application form as well as failure to accompany the application with the payment of the prescribed fee
shall be deemed just cause for denying the application with prejudice.
(e)
Upon proper completion of the application and payment of fees, city manager or the city manager's designee shall refer the
application to the director of public safety. Thereafter, the director of public safety shall present his findings and
recommendations to the city commission.
(f)
As a prerequisite to the issuance of a license, all businesses where liquor by the drink is consumed on the premises shall
satisfy all requirements of a fire and life safety inspection performed by the local fire official and city building official or
his/her designee. The prescribed inspection form shall be provided by the local fire official. In addition, all businesses
where liquor by the drink is consumed on the premises and the occupancy load is one hundred (100) or more, shall provide
the city manager or the city manager's designee with a signed fire safety report and certificate of occupancy from the state
fire marshal's office. The local fire official may cause to be inspected any building or portion of any building licensed under
this article.
(g)
Upon full compliance with the requirements of the fire and life safety inspections, the local fire official shall notify the city
manager or the city manager's designee for further processing of the license.
(h)
After its investigation, the city manager or the city manager's designee, with the approval of the city commission, shall
grant or deny the license applied for.
(i)
If the application is denied, the application fee shall not be refunded.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
82/489
Sec. 3-125. - Renewal.
All liquor by the drink licensees shall be required to apply for renewal of their licenses annually on forms prescribed by the
city clerk and must comply with all provisions of this article, with the exception that publication of notice, fingerprinting
and background checks, as required shall not be required for renewal of a license unless there has been a change of
ownership of the business or other interests therein. On renewal, the applicant shall be administered and take the oath
specifically contained on the application form. The city manager or the city manager's designee may within their discretion
require fingerprinting and a full background check on any renewal at any time.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-126. - Transfer.
(a)
Except as provided in this section, no license shall be transferable to any other person or location.
(b)
If a licensee seeks to move his place of business from the licensee's premises to another place within the city, application
shall be made as for an original license.
(c)
In the case of death of an owner of a license or financial interest therein, such license or interest therein may be transferred
to the administrator, executor, or adult heir or heirs of the deceased unless the city manager or the city manager's designee,
with the approval of the city commission, determines that it would otherwise violate this article. If the transferee cannot
meet all the requirements of this article when the time comes to renew the license, it shall not be renewed.
(d)
Nothing in this section shall prohibit one (1) or more partners in a partnership from retiring therefrom in favor of one (1) or
more of the other partners; provided such withdrawal shall not without application for an issuance of a new license
introduce any new partner or result in any new person acquiring an interest in the licensed business.
(e)
Where a license is issued to a corporation having as its principal business an activity other than the sale of liquor by the
drink, a change in the named licensee may be permitted by the city manager or the city manager's designee, with the
approval of the city commission, if the new named licensee meets the requirements of new license applicants.
(f)
In the circumstances described in subsections (c), (d) and (e) of this section, the license may be revoked if the city
commission determines that the change results in a failure to meet the requirements of this article.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-127. - Change in business ownership.
(a)
If any licensee withdraws from, sells or otherwise transfers the licensee's interest in the licensed business, the licensee shall
within two (2) days, notify the city manager and surrender the license.
(b)
In the case of such a withdrawal, transfer, or sale, a new application shall be made as for an original license.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
83/489
Sec. 3-128. - Temporary license.
(a)
A temporary license may be issued by the city manager or the city manager's designee, with the approval of the city
commission, if, in their judgment, the denial of a temporary license would create an undue hardship such as the closing of
an existing business. The temporary license shall be issued for an extra fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for a ninety-day period
with one (1) additional ninety-day extension if needed.
(b)
A temporary license may be revoked, with or without cause, by the city commission at any time, and the grant or denial of
a temporary license shall not affect or have any bearing upon the grant or denial of a permanent license.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-129. - Suspension/revocation.
(a)
A license may be suspended or revoked by the city commission for any violation of this article and/or other city
ordinances, for any violation of state or federal law, for any material misrepresentation or omission in the application for
the license, or if the licensee or the licensed business ceases to meet the eligibility requirements for license. The city
manager shall schedule a due process hearing before the city commission for any license holder alleged to have violated
any provision of this article by sending at least fourteen (14) days prior to the date of the due process hearing, a certified
letter to the license holder containing the date, time, and location of the hearing, the date and nature of the allegations, and
the license holder's right to be represented by an attorney and to present evidence. In lieu of a certified letter, the city
manager may elect to have service perfected by personal service by a city police officer.
(b)
The city commission is authorized to suspend the sale of liquor by the drink under any license for any emergency situation
such that the city commission finds that such suspension necessary for the protection of the public health, safety, or
welfare. Such suspension may be made effective immediately and may remain in force until the city commission
determines that the emergency is over or until the next meeting of the city commission, at which time the suspension shall
cease unless it is extended by the city commission.
(c)
A licensee, or any citizen of the city, who is dissatisfied with the decision of the city commission, may appeal to the
Superior Court of Crisp County, Georgia. Any appeal from a decision of the city commission must be filed within thirty
(30) days after such decision.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-130. - Automatic revocation.
A license shall be automatically revoked by operation of law if:
(1)
The licensee's state alcoholic beverage license is revoked, suspended, canceled or not renewed.
(2)
Payment of the annual license fee is not received by the city within fourteen (14) days after notification that the approval to
issue a license has been made by the city commission.
(3)
Operation of the licensed activity is not commenced within six (6) months after the license is issued.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
84/489
(4)
Operation of the licensed activity is commenced and then discontinued for a period of thirty (30) days unless extended by
the city commission for good cause.
(5)
The licensed business fails to properly account for, file report and pay any excise tax levied and due under this article.
(6)
The licensed business fails to properly account for, file, report or maintain any records or remit any license fee imposed or
taxes required under this article.
(7)
Payment of the annual renewal license fee is not received by the city within the time prescribed.
(8)
The named licensee is convicted of a felony by a court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Secs. 3-131—3-135. - Reserved.
DIVISION 3. - LOCATION
Sec. 3-136. - Sale/service in public places.
It shall be unlawful to furnish or dispense liquor by the drink in public places, or to be consumed in public places.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-137. - Proximity restrictions.
(a)
No person may sell or offer to sell:
(1)
a.
Liquor by the drink in or within one hundred (100) yards of any church building or within two hundred (200) yards of any
school building, educational building, school grounds, or college campus. This subsection shall not apply at any location
for which a new license is applied for if the sale of liquor by the drink was lawful at such location at any time during the
twelve (12) months immediately preceding such application, unless the location does not have adequate parking to
accommodate the restaurant or private club. Adequacy of parking under this subsection shall be determined as required by
the zoning ordinance of the City of Cordele.
b.
A church building in a business zoning district is defined as a free-standing structure built for and used as a church, and
does not apply to commercial or retail space that has been converted to occupancy as a church.
(2)
Liquor by the drink within one hundred (100) yards of an alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by this state or
any county or municipal government therein. This subsection shall not apply to any business having a license in effect
within six (6) months after the final adoption of this article.
(3)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
85/489
Nothing contained in this article shall prohibit the licensing of the sale or distribution of liquor by the drink by:
(b)
Bona fide private clubs, owning their own premises, subject to licensing under state law.
(c)
For the purposes of this article, distances shall be measured by drawing a straight line from the nearest point of the outside
wall conditioned (mechanically heated or cooled) space of the applicant's business establishment to the nearest point of
either (a) the outside wall enclosing conditional (mechanically heated or cooled) space of a church, school, or educational
building, or (b) the real property of a school grounds or college campus.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Secs. 3-138—3-140. - Reserved.
DIVISION 4. - SALES
Sec. 3-141. - Responsibility of named licensee.
The named licensee shall be active in the operation of the licensed business and shall be personally present on the licensed
premises sufficiently to assure compliance with the provisions of this article.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-142. - Rentals paid restricted.
Except as otherwise provided in this article, it shall be unlawful for a licensee to enter into any agreement whereby the
rental paid for licensed premises is based in whole or in part on the volume of sales of liquor by the drink by the licensed
business or whereby the lessor otherwise shares in the profits or receipts from the licensed business's sale of liquor by the
drink.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-143. - Display of license.
Each license issued under this article shall at all times be kept plainly exposed to view upon the licensed premises.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-144. - Retention of records.
(a)
Each licensee shall keep and preserve records of all alcohol and alcoholic beverages purchased and all liquor by the drink
sold by the licensee and shall keep and preserve records of all food and non-alcoholic beverages purchased and sold by
them. Such records shall at all times during normal business hours be open for inspection by an authorized agent of the
city. Such records shall be maintained for a period of at least three (3) years.
(b)
All liquor by the drink licensees shall file with the city clerk the following reports by 5:00 p.m. on the 20th day of each
month:
(1)
An on-premises consumption report of liquor by the drink.
(2)
Certified copies of the licensee's state sales tax reports as filed with the state department of revenue.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
86/489
(3)
Any other documents, reports, records, or books as shall be required by the city commission to confirm the accuracy of the
reported information.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06; Ord. No. 0-06-08, § 3, 5-16-06)
Sec. 3-145. - Knowledge of article pro visions.
Every licensee shall, prior to applying for a license, read and familiarize himself with the provisions of this article and an
application shall constitute a certification by the applicant that he has done so. Every licensee shall maintain a copy of this
article on the licensed premises and shall instruct each employee engaged in the sale or handling of alcoholic beverages on
the relevant provisions of this article.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-146. - Sales to underage persons prohibited.
Furnishing to, purchase of or possession of [by] persons under the age of twenty-one (21) years of age of liquor by the
drink (or any form of alcohol) shall be controlled by state law O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23. Additionally, any alleged violation of
this subsection by a license holder, or its or his employee(s), shall result in a due process hearing before the city
commission being called by the city manager to determine if a license should be suspended or revoked.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-147. - Days of sales prohibited.
(a)
No licensee shall permit the sale of alcoholic beverages on any day or any time when such sales are prohibited by state law.
(b)
The sale of liquor by the drink shall be lawful during the polling hours of any election.
(c)
No licensee shall permit the sale of liquor by the drink on Sunday.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-148. - Sales to intoxicated persons; gambling; disorderly conduct.
(a)
No licensee shall permit the sale of liquor by the drink to any person who is in a state of noticeable intoxication or allow
persons who are noticeably intoxicated to congregate on licensed premises.
(b)
No licensee shall permit any gambling, betting, illegal lottery, or other device to hazard money or other thing of value on
the licensed premises, except that this prohibition shall not apply with respect to a properly licensed bingo game.
(c)
No licensee shall permit on the licensed premises any disorderly conduct, breach of the peace, or noise or activity which is
disturbing to the surrounding neighborhood.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-149. - Container, storage, illumination.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
87/489
(a)
Alcoholic beverages shall be delivered to and received at licensed premises only in the original container and only in a
conveyance owned and operated by a licensed wholesale dealer (or a licensed common carrier acting for a wholesaler).
Alcoholic beverages shall be sold at retail only as liquor by the drink on the licensed premises.
(b)
A retail licensee shall store alcoholic beverages only on the licensed premises and at no other place. All stock shall be
available at all times for inspection by an authorized agent of the city. Any alcoholic beverages found in any retail
licensee's stock which were not received from a wholesaler licensed to make deliveries in the city shall be subject to
immediate confiscation.
(c)
The exterior of each building in which alcoholic beverages are sold for consumption on the premises shall contain
sufficient lighting so that all sides of the building and all entrances thereto are clearly visible at all times.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-150. - Cleanliness of premises; inspections.
All licensed premises shall be kept clean and in proper sanitary condition and in full compliance with all regulations
governing the condition of premises used for the storage and sale of food for human consumption. All licensed premises
shall be open at all times for inspection by authorized agents of the city.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-151. - Employees of on-premises consumption liquor by the drink licensees; permit required.
(a)
The following regulations regarding employees shall apply to all establishments holding a license for liquor by the drink on
the premises:
(1)
No person shall be employed by an establishment holding a license hereunder until such person has been issued a permit
indicating that such person is eligible for this employment. However, a seven-day grace period shall be given from the date
of employment until the permit is issued. The permit shall be provisional until the director of public safety has had
applicant fingerprinted, photographed and cleared by the public safety department after a computerized background check.
If the applicant's background check reveals a record that would make the employee ineligible to keep a permit, the director
of public safety shall revoke the permit. The permit issued to a person under this section shall be an alcohol service permit,
which shall be issued only to a person who must be at least eighteen (18) years of age and who sells, serves or dispenses
liquor by the drink: or is employed as a manager, host, hostess, doorman or bouncer in such establishment. A permit shall
be valid for a two-year period, and shall be renewed on or before its expiration.
(2)
The director of public safety or his designee shall investigate all applications for alcohol service permits made pursuant to
this section. The director of public safety may refuse to issue an alcohol service permit to any proposed employee who:
a.
Has been convicted of a felony within a period of five (5) years immediately prior to the date upon which the application
for an alcohol service permit was made.
b.
Has been convicted of two (2) or more misdemeanors within two (2) years immediately preceding the application for an
alcohol service permit. Misdemeanors will be defined as violations other than minor traffic violations such as speeding,
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
88/489
stop sign, failure to yield, following too closely, etc. The two (2) convictions for misdemeanor violations for which the
violator was convicted should have arisen at different times.
c.
Has been convicted within a period of five (5) years immediately preceding the application of any of the following
offenses:
1.
Pandering, prostitution or soliciting prostitution;
2.
Gambling;
3.
Illegal sale of controlled substance or narcotic;
4.
Where the record indicates such employee would adversely affect the public health, safety or welfare or violate the law.
d.
This subsection shall apply with respect to the laws of this state, other states, the United States, and other countries. A plea
of nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond shall be considered a conviction for the purposes of this subsection.
(3)
A permit shall be issued provisionally in the first seven (7) days of employment upon a signed application and payment of
the application fee having been filed with the director of public safety; until a search of the criminal record of the applicant
has been completed. The application fee shall be as set by the city commission. Such application shall include, but shall not
be limited to, the name, date of birth and prior arrest record of the applicant, though the feet of an arrest record shall be
used for investigative purposes only, and shall give rise to no presumption or inference of guilt. Due to the inclusion of
arrest information, these applications shall be regarded as confidential and shall not be produced for public inspection
without a court order.
(4)
The director of public safety shall have a complete and exhaustive search made relative to any police record of the person
fingerprinted or cleared. In the event there is no record of a violation of this article, the director of public safety shall issue
a permit to the employee, stating that the person is eligible for employment. If it is found that the person fingerprinted or
cleared is not eligible for employment, the director of public safety shall notify by letter the applicant and the employer that
this person is not eligible for employment.
(5)
It shall be the duty of all persons holding any license to sell liquor by the drink to file with the director of public safety as
part of their liquor by the drink license renewal application the name of the establishment, the license number and a list of
all employees, with their most recent local addresses and telephone numbers, and social security numbers. An applicant for
an initial license shall furnish the same information prior to the date when on premise consumption sales are authorized to
begin.
(6)
All permits issued through administrative error or through an error in completion of a background investigation can be
terminated by the director of public safety.
(7)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
89/489
This section shall not be construed to include employees whose duties are limited solely to those of delivery driver, busboy,
cook, or dishwasher.
(8)
No licensee shall allow any employee required to hold a permit to work on the licensed premises unless the licensee has on
file, on the premises, a clearly legible copy of the current, valid permit of each such employee. The employee must keep
the original permit on his person when at work in a licensed establishment, though it need not be publicly displayed.
(9)
In the event that any permit holder leaves the employ of a licensed establishment, the licensee shall immediately notify the
city police department.
(10)
All permits issued hereunder remain the property of the city and shall be produced for inspection upon the demand of any
officer of the city police department or a state law enforcement officer with jurisdiction in such matters.
(11)
The director of public safety may revoke the permit and demand its return where the employee violates the provisions of
this article or becomes one who adversely affects the public health, safety, or welfare. The first such offense shall result in a
suspension of the permit for one hundred twenty (120) days. Any subsequent offense shall result in revocation of the
permit, and the employee being ineligible to reapply for such a permit.
(12)
When any employee permit is revoked, the director of public safety shall issue a letter to the permit holder, and a copy to
the licensee for whom he works, stating that the person does not meet the requirements of this article.
(13)
It shall be unlawful for an employee whose permit has been revoked and upon whom demand for return of the card has
been made, to refuse to return the card, or to alter, conceal, deface, or destroy the card.
(14)
A new search may be conducted on any person issued a permit if the chief of police receives information which warrants
such a new search. If the new search reveals evidence that warrants revocation of the permit, he may revoke the permit.
(b)
Nothing herein shall in any way be construed to limit the liability of the licensee for the conduct of its employees. Any
violation of this article by an employee remains a violation of this article by the licensee, who is subject to fines,
suspension, or revocation as set forth herein.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-152. - Drive-through sales of alcoholic beverages prohibited.
(a)
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any alcoholic beverage within the city by means of drive-through
sale.
(b)
For purposes of this article, the term "drive-through sale" means the sale of alcoholic beverages by any means that allows
the customer to remain in his vehicle.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
90/489
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
DIVISION 5. - EMPLOYMENT OF UNDERAGE PERSONS
Sec. 3-153. - General prohibitions.
(a)
No wholesale liquor by the drink licensee shall allow any employee under the age of eighteen (18) years to dispense, sell,
serve, take orders for, or handle alcoholic beverages.
(b)
This section shall not prohibit the employment of persons under the above ages on licensed premises where such persons
do not dispense, sell, serve, take orders for, or handle alcoholic beverages.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-154. - Brown-bagging prohibited.
It shall be unlawful for a licensee to allow customers to bring onto the licensed premises their own alcoholic beverages,
which is known as "bring your own bottle" (BYOB) or "brown-bagging".
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Secs. 3-155—3-158. - Reserved.
DIVISION 6. - CONSUMPTION ON PREMISES
Sec. 3-159. - Eligibility restricted—Generally.
A liquor by the drink license may be granted only to a restaurant, as defined under section 3-160 and a private club as
defined under section 3-161.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-160. - Same—Restaurant.
In order to be eligible for a liquor by the drink license, a restaurant shall:
(1)
Be used and held out to the public as a place where meals prepared on the premises are regularly served to the public for
adequate pay each day the establishment is open for business;
(2)
Contain one (1) or more public dining rooms, with adequate and sanitary kitchen facilities and refrigeration as required by
the Crisp County Health Department and staff to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests;
(3)
Have the ability to serve meals prepared on the premises during any time the establishment is open for business;
(4)
Have a valid Crisp County Health Department food service permit and any other applicable local, state or federal permits,
licenses, etc. required for food service establishments;
(5)
Have at least sixty (60) percent of its total sales comprised of the sale of food prepared on the premises and nonalcoholic
beverages consumed on the premises; and for this purpose, if a restaurant makes a minimum charge, cover charge, or
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
91/489
admission charge, or any other non-food or non-alcoholic beverage charge, the amount so charged shall not be counted in
computing total sales and shall not be counted as a food or beverage sale;
(6)
Have a permanent seating capacity at tables, not counting bar stools, of at least twenty-five (25) persons.
(7)
The occupancy load for purposes of this section must meet the following criteria:
a.
The square footage of the interior area of the restaurant, which is enclosed and under roof and is conditioned air space,
shall be determined using a set of building plans showing the fixed and other seating and tables.
b.
The food preparation service areas (kitchen, buffet and salad bar areas), storage, the preparation area behind bars,
restrooms and all connecting hallways shall be removed from the total square footage of the floor space.
c.
The maximum occupant load for the remaining areas shall be calculated in accordance with the building code and life
safety code as follows:
1.
The assembly area where restaurant seating is located shall be calculated using fifteen (15) square feet per person.
2.
The waiting area at the entrance/exit shall be calculated using three (3) square feet per person. The number of occupants
allowed in the calculation for waiting area cannot exceed fifty (50) percent of the occupant load of the assembly area in
subsection 1. above.
3.
An additional area for live entertainment and dancing shall be calculated using seven (7) square feet per person. The
number of occupants allowed in the calculation for this additional area cannot exceed twenty (20) percent of the occupant
load of the assembly areas in subsection 1. above.
4.
The city commission may consider a request for consumption on the premises of a deck or patio attached or adjacent to the
principal restaurant assembly area. If such a request is granted, it does not alter the calculation of the maximum occupant
load.
d.
The occupancy load determined by the City manager for each location shall be posted for public view.
(8)
Maintain at all times the number of tables, chairs, and booths for patrons in substantially the same general configuration as
submitted on the set of building plans used to determine the occupancy load. Nothing herein shall prohibit the temporary
placing of tables together to accommodate a larger dining party, provided the total number of tables, chairs and booths
available for patron use in the assembly area where restaurant seating is located must equal the number shown on the
building plans submitted for occupancy purposes, with adequate space between them for normal movement of patrons and
employees. The intent of this provision is to prohibit the removal at any time of the restaurant's seating or table capacity, as
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
92/489
shown for occupancy load purposes, to accommodate more than the allowed number of patrons within the assembly area of
the restaurant.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-161. - Private club.
(a)
In order to be eligible for a liquor by the drink license, a private club must be a veterans organization, fraternal organization
or other nonprofit organization all of which must be incorporated, and:
(1)
The local chapter has been in existence at least five (5) years prior to the filing of its application for a license;
(2)
Have a least forty (40) regular dues-paying members;
(3)
Be organized and operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation and other nonprofit purposes;
(4)
Own, hire, or lease a building or space within a building for the reasonable use of its members.
(b)
Has no member, officer, agent, or employee directly or indirectly receiving in the form of salary or other compensation any
profits from the sale of alcoholic beverages beyond a fixed salary.
(c)
No liquor by the drink license shall be granted to a private club organized or operated primarily for the selling or serving of
alcoholic beverages.
(d)
Private clubs licensed under the provisions of this section shall not be required to maintain the percentage sale of food/nonalcoholic beverages as compared to alcoholic beverages, however such organization shall be subject to all regulations of
this article dealing with general licensing and consumption of liquor by the drink on the premises.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-162. - Ratio of alcoholic/non-alcoholic sales.
Should the total sales from food and non-alcoholic beverages reported by any liquor by the drink licensee not equal those
from the sale of all alcoholic beverages for any two (2) consecutive reporting periods, or for two (2) non-consecutive
reporting periods in any twelve-month period, the license may be suspended or revoked by the city commission after a
hearing as provided for in section 3-129.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-163. - Reserved.
Sec. 3-164. - Illumination of premises, location of sales restricted.
(a)
All restaurants including all tables, booths, and other areas where customers are served and including all passageways for
customers, shall be sufficiently well illuminated so that they may be viewed by those inside the premises.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
93/489
(b)
The sale of alcoholic beverages in any back room or side room which is not open to the general public is prohibited, except
that this prohibition shall not apply with respect to:
(1)
Private parties which have been scheduled in advance;
(2)
Room service to hotel guests in their hotel rooms, provided a properly licensed restaurant is located on the premises;
(3)
Private clubs.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-165. - Hours of sale.
Liquor by the drink licensees shall only engage in the sale and service of liquor by the drink between the hours of 6:00 a.m.
and 1:00 a.m. Monday through Friday, with consumption of purchased beverages on the premises until 2:00 a.m.; on
Saturday from 6:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-166. - Dancing on premises prohibited.
Patron dancing shall be permitted at facilities licensed for liquor by the drink sales only where:
(1)
Adequate space exists;
(2)
All fire and safety regulations are met.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-167. - Removal of beverages prohibited.
All alcoholic beverages sold by liquor by the drink licensees shall be consumed only on the licensed premises. It shall be
unlawful for any person to remove from the licensed premises any alcoholic beverages sold for consumption on the
premises to any public streets, sidewalks or rights-of-way, or in any public or semipublic parking facility within the city.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-168. - Prohibition of certain types of entertainment, attire and conduct.
(a)
Findings; public purpose. Based on the experience of other urban counties and municipalities, including, but not limited to,
Atlanta and Fulton County, Georgia; DeKalb County, Georgia; Richmond County, Georgia; Amarillo, Texas; Austin,
Texas; Garden Grove, California; Houston, Texas; Renton, Washington; Phoenix, Arizona; Indianapolis, Indiana; St. Paul,
Minnesota; Tucson, Arizona; Augusta, Georgia; LaGrange, Georgia; Dalton and Whitfield County, Georgia; Carrollton,
Georgia; Smyrna, Georgia; and Ft. Lauderdale and Palm Beach, Florida, which experiences the city commission believes
are relevant to the problems faced by the City of Cordele, the city commission takes note of the notorious and self-evident
conditions attendant to the commercial exploitation of human sexuality, which do not vary greatly among generally
comparable communities within our country. Moreover, it is the finding of the city commission that public nudity (either
partial or total) under certain circumstances, particularly circumstances related to the sale and consumption of alcoholic
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
94/489
beverages, begets criminal behavior and tends to create undesirable community conditions. Among the acts of criminal
behavior identified with nudity and alcohol are disorderly conduct, prostitution, and drug trafficking and use. Among the
undesirable community conditions identified with nudity and alcohol are depression of property values in the surrounding
neighborhood, increased expenditure for and allocation of law enforcement personnel to preserve law and order, increased
burden on the judicial system as a consequence of the criminal behavior herein above described, and acceleration of
community blight by the concentration of such establishments in particular areas. Therefore, the limitation of nude conduct
in establishments licensed to sell alcoholic beverages is in the public welfare and it is a matter of governmental interest,
and concern to prevent the occurrence of criminal behavior and undesirable community conditions normally associated
with establishments which serve alcohol and also allow and/or encourage nudity. To that end, this section is hereby
adopted.
(b)
Enactment. The following types of entertainment, attire and conduct are prohibited upon any premises licensed to sell,
serve or disperse liquor by the drink.
(1)
The employment or use of any person, in any capacity, in the sale or service of liquor by the drink while such person is
unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing, as to expose to view any portion of the female breast below the top of the
areola or any portion of the male or female pubic hair, anus, cleft or the buttocks, vulva and genitals.
(2)
Live entertainment where any person appears in the manner described in subsection (1) of this subsection.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-169. - Pricing of liquor by the drink.
(a)
This section shall be construed to cover, include and apply to liquor by the drink.
(b)
No licensee or holder of a license to sell liquor by the drink, or employee or agent of a licensee, shall:
(1)
Offer to deliver any free liquor by the drink.
(2)
Deliver more than one (1) liquor drink to one (1) person at one (1) time, or allow any patron to possess more than one (1)
liquor drink at one (1) time.
(3)
Sell, offer to sell, or deliver to any person or group of persons two (2) or more or an unlimited number of liquor drinks
during any set period of time at a fixed price, except at private functions not open to the public.
(4)
Sell, offer to sell, or deliver liquor by the drink to any person or group of persons on any one (1) day at prices less than
those charged to the general public on that day, except at private functions not open to the public.
(5)
Sponsor, conduct, encourage or allow on the licensed premises any game or contest or promotion which either:
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
95/489
a.
Involves the drinking of alcoholic beverages or the awarding of alcoholic beverages as the prize; or
b.
Has as its primary purpose the increasing of the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises.
(6)
Sell, offer to sell, or deliver to a customer liquor by the drink in any container other than a glass or plastic cup.
(7)
Sell, offer to sell, deliver, or allow any alcoholic beverage to be inserted into the mouth of a customer in any manner by
anyone other than by the customer.
(8)
Charge any minimum charge, cover charge, admission charge, or any other non-food or non-alcoholic beverage charge
which discriminates on the basis of gender, race, age, creed, or national origin.
(9)
Deny entry or service to any person at any time on the basis of gender, race, age, creed, or national origin.
(c)
No provision of this section shall be construed to prohibit licensees from offering free food or entertainment at any time, or
to prohibit any hotel or motel from offering room services to registered guests.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-170. - Misrepresentation of alcoholic beverages.
It shall be unlawful for licensees under this article or their agents to add to the contents of a bottle or to refill empty bottles
or in any other manner to misrepresent the quantity, quality or brand name of any alcoholic beverage.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Secs. 3-171—3-173. - Reserved.
DIVISION 7. - EXCISE TAX ON MIXED DRINKS
Sec. 3-174. - Imposition.
There is imposed upon the sale of liquor by the drink in the city a tax in the amount of three (3) percent of the purchase
price of each drink to the consumer. Each licensee shall be allowed a deduction of three (3) percent of the amount of taxes
collected as reimbursement for collection of such taxes; provided that such tax is not delinquent at the time of payment. A
record of each sale will be made in writing and maintained for inspection by any authorized agent of the city.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-175. - Collection.
Every liquor by the drink licensee shall collect the tax imposed by this article from purchasers of all such drinks. The
licensee shall furnish such information as may be required by the city commission to facilitate the collection of the tax. In
all cases where the purchase is by deferred payment or credit, the licensee becomes liable for the collection and payment of
the tax at the time of delivery of such drink to the purchasers.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Sec. 3-176. - Payment to city.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
96/489
(a)
Each licensee shall pay over the amount of taxes collected and coming due under this article in every calendar month to the
city not later than the twentieth day of the following calendar month.
(b)
On or before the twentieth day of each month, a return shall be filed with the city clerk for the preceding month by each
licensee liable for the payment of tax under this article. Returns shall be in such form as the city clerk may specify and
shall show the licensee's gross receipts from the sale of liquor by the drink and the amount of taxes collected or coming due
thereon.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06; Ord. No. 0-06-08, § 1, 5-16-06)
DIVISION 8. - EFFECTIVE DATE
Sec. 3-177. - Effective date.
This article shall become effective on May 15,2006.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Secs. 3-178—3-180. - Reserved.
DIVISION 9. - SEVERABILITY
Sec. 3-181. - Provisions herein are severable.
Should any provision herein be declared unconstitutional or illegal by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining
provisions shall remain of full force and effect.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
DIVISION 10. - SHORT TITLE
Sec. 3-182. - Short title.
This article shall be known as and may be cited as Cordele 2006 Liquor by the Drink Ordinance.
(Ord. No. 0-06-05, 4-18-06)
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL
