Sec. 14-41. - Definitions.
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article:
Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, or organization of any kind.
Property means any real property within the city which is not a street or highway.
Short title means the name by which this article may be known, cited, and construed.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
226/489
Street or highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part
thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel.
Vehicle means a machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel along the ground by use of
wheels, treads, runners, or slides and transport persons or property or pull machinery and shall include, without limitation,
automobile, truck, trailer, motorcycle, tractor, buggy, and wagon.
(Ord. No. 0-01-23, 5-1-01; Ord. No. 0-09-04, 11-3-09)
Sec. 14-42. - Abandonment of vehicle.
No person shall abandon any vehicle within the city and no person shall leave any vehicle at any place within the city for
such time and under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle reasonably to appear to have been abandoned.
(Ord. No. 0-01-23, 5-1-01; Ord. No. 0-09-04, 11-3-09)
Sec. 14-43. - Disposition of wrecked or discarded vehicles.
No person in charge or control of any property within the city, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, or otherwise,
shall allow any partially dismantled, non-operating, wrecked, junked, or discarded vehicle to remain on such property
longer than seventy-two (72) hours; and no person shall leave any such vehicle on any property within the city for a longer
time than seventy-two (72) hours; except that this article shall not apply with regard to a vehicle in an enclosed building; a
vehicle on the premises of a business enterprise operating in a lawful place and manner, when necessary to the operation of
such business enterprise; or a vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner
by the city.
Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, in the event there are multiple vehicles involved in the enforcement of the
Abandoned Vehicles Ordinance, the director of community development and his/her designee are hereby authorized, in
their sole and absolute discretion, to grant to the person whose vehicles are in violation of said ordinance, additional time
for the removal of said vehicles but in no case shall the extension of time exceed thirty (30) days unless a further extension
is granted by the city commission.
(Ord. No. 0-01-23, 5-1-01; Ord. No. 0-09-04, 11-3-09)
Sec. 14-44. - Impounding.
The director of community development and his/ her designee are hereby authorized to remove or have removed any
vehicle left at any place within the city which reasonably appears to be in violation of this article or lost, stolen, or
unclaimed. Such vehicle may be impounded until lawfully claimed or disposed of in accordance with the following:
(1)
Any such vehicle may be removed by city personnel and equipment or private licensed wrecker/removal service and stored
at a fenced area located on city property.
a.
A removal fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be charged and become a lien against any such vehicle.
b.
A daily storage fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be charged and become a lien against any such vehicle.
c.
The Cordele Police Department shall conduct the procedures set forth in O.C.G.A. § 40-11-2, as amended, on each such
vehicle.
d.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
227/489
If any such vehicle has been unclaimed for ninety (90) days after impoundment and storage, the lien against the vehicle for
removal and storage shall be foreclosed in the Magistrate Court of Crisp County, Georgia, within one (1) year of
impoundment according to provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-11-5, as amended.
e.
Sale of any such vehicle shall be according to provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-11-6, as amended.
f.
Disposition of the proceeds of any such sale shall be according to provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-11-8, as amended.
(Ord. No. 0-01-23, 5-1-01; Ord. No. 0-09-04, 11-3-09)
Sec. 14-45. - Penalties.
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article upon conviction in the Municipal Court of the City of Cordele
thereof shall be fined within the limits set forth in Section 7.03 of the Charter of the City of Cordele. Each day such
violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such
hereunder.
(Ord. No. 0-01-23, 5-1-01; Ord. No. 0-09-04, 11-3-09)
Sec. 14-46. - Severability.
If any provision of this article is found illegal or unconstitutional, the remaining provisions shall continue to be
enforceable.
(Ord. No. 0-01-23, 5-1-01; Ord. No. 0-09-04, 11-3-09)
Sec. 14-47. - Conflicting ordinances repealed.
Any existing ordinances of code sections of the Code of the City of Cordele in conflict with this article are expressly
repealed.
(Ord. No. 0-01-23, 5-1-01; Ord. No. 0-09-04, 11-3-09)
Chapter 15 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) ---
Cross reference— Construction contracts, § 2-71 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; business licenses and
regulations, Ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 9; peaceful picketing, § 12-5; noise, § 12-6; solid waste management,
Ch. 14; utilities, Ch. 18.
State Law reference— Authority to construct and maintain streets and roads, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3; powers with
respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; power of city to open, close or extend public streets, alleys and
sidewalks, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; street improvements, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-1 et seq.; executions for collection of assessments
for paving streets and laying sewers, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-358.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 15-1. - Building numbers.
(a)
All property owners or lessees of property located in this city shall provide, of suitable material, a number for each
premises located upon such property; such numerals shall be placed in a conspicuous place on the premises.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
228/489
(b)
It shall be the duty of the city department of community development, upon application by any lessee or property owner in
the city, to furnish the lessee or the property owner with the correct number of the premises.
(c)
Should any lessee or property owner in the city fail or refuse for the space of twenty (20) days after the completion of any
premises thereon or after notification in writing by the director of community development to place upon the premises the
number thereof in the manner herein designated, it shall be lawful for the city to furnish and place upon the premises such
number and upon a bill rendered stating the amount or cost of same, upon the affidavit of the city engineer, the clerk shall
issue instanter an execution for the amount against the owner or lessee and against the property, which execution shall issue
and proceed as executions for taxes due the city.
(Code 1977, § 19-1)
Sec. 15-2. - Construction specifications.
All streets and sidewalks in the city shall be constructed or repaired in accordance with the development regulations of the
city.
(Code 1977, § 19-2)
Sec. 15-3. - Excavations.
No person shall excavate, dig in or haul any dirt from any of the streets, alleys or commons of the city without written
permission of the city manager.
(Code 1977, § 19-3)
Sec. 15-4. - Obstructions—Generally.
No person shall deposit, place or put, or cause to be deposited, placed or put, any vehicles of any kind, or any goods, wares,
merchandise, firewood, boxes, barrels, casks, logs, bottles, cans or any other obstruction in or upon the streets, alleys or
sidewalks of the city, so as to obstruct the free passage and use of the same. This section shall not be construed to prohibit
the use of the streets, alleys and sidewalks for the necessary reception and delivery of any goods, wares or merchandise, or
to prevent workmen employed in building or doing other necessary work, from depositing lumber, brick, mortar, other
building material and the remains of old building materials on the streets, alleys and sidewalks contiguous thereto, but such
workmen shall obstruct the same as little as possible, and remove the materials as soon as it can be done consistently with
the prosecution of the work in which they are engaged.
(Code 1977, § 19-4)
State law reference— Obstructing sidewalks or other public passages, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-43.
Sec. 15-5. - Same—Display of goods on sidewalk.
It shall be unlawful for any person doing business within the city to expose for sale, display or otherwise arrange or place
any goods, wares or merchandise of any character on the sidewalks of the city.
(Code 1977, § 19-5)
Sec. 15-6. - Distributing bills or circulars.
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, deposit or place, or cause to be thrown, deposited or placed, or to give away
upon the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city, any circulars, bills or other advertising matter without first having obtained
from the city manager a permit for such purpose.
(Code 1977, § 19-6)
Sec. 15-7. - Posting bills, etc.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
229/489
It shall be unlawful for any person to place, post or affix any advertising matter of any kind whatever on or to any light
post, telephone post, telegraph post or electric wire post in any public street or alley within the city.
(Code 1977, § 19-7)
Sec. 15-8. - Placing banners, etc., across streets.
It shall be unlawful for any person to extend any banner or sign across any public street, park or other way of the city
without first having obtained permission from the city manager.
(Code 1977, § 19-8)
Sec. 15-9. - Advertising matter in streets.
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or post any advertising matter or promotional sign of any kind in the streets
within the city.
(Code 1977, § 19-9)
State law reference— Regulation of signs used by retail distilled spirits dealer, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-3; prohibited placement of
campaign posters, signs and advertisements, O.C.G.A. § 21-1-1; unlawful placement of signs within right-of-way of public
road, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-51; regulation of outdoor advertising in vicinity of interstate highways, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-70 et seq.
Sec. 15-10. - Fires prohibited.
No person shall kindle or build any fire upon any sidewalk, street or public grounds of this city.
(Code 1977, § 19-10)
Sec. 15-11. - Removal of obstacles.
(a)
Obstructions placed upon the streets, alleys, or sidewalks of the city in violation of section 15-4 of this chapter may be
summarily removed by the city police department if such prevents or materially interferes with the proper and legitimate
use of the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city.
(b)
Obstructions removed as aforesaid shall be temporarily stored on city property at a location designated by the city manager.
(c)
If the owner of such removed obstructions is known, he or she shall be issued a summons to appear at the municipal court
of the city, and the judge of said court is hereby empowered to order the disposition of such obstructions by the owner.
Failure of the owner to follow such order shall be unlawful and subject the owner to such punishment as the judge of said
court may determine appropriate.
(d)
If the owner of such obstructions is not known, and cannot be determined upon a reasonable investigation by the police
department, such obstructions shall be considered abandoned property and disposed of as the law provides.
(Ord. No. 0-98-23, § 1, 7-21-98)
Secs. 15-12—15-40. - Reserved.
ARTICLE II. - TREE PRESERVATION
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) ---
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
230/489
Editor's note— Ord. No. 0-93-6, adopted May 18, 1993, enacted provisions which have been included herein at the
discretion of the editor as Art. II, §§ 15-41—15-55.
Cross reference— Cemeteries, Ch. 7.
Sec. 15-41. - Purpose and intent.
It is the purpose and intent of this article to beautify the city by properly managing the preservation of trees on city
property using approved horticultural procedures; to encourage orderly addition of trees to city property in the interest of
improving the ecology and environment of the city; and to set a further example to the general public of the city
commission's determination to establish Cordele as a model city in every respect.
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 1, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 1, 10-19-93)
Sec. 15-42. - Definitions.
As used in this article the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed:
Flowering trees are herein defined as multi-stemmed from single-stemmed which will normally grow to a height of less
than twenty (20) feet.
Park trees: "Park trees" are herein defined as single-stemmed woody vegetation which will normally grow to a height of
more than twenty (20) feet located on all lands belonging to the city other than streets, avenues and alleys.
Street trees: "Street trees" are herein defined as single-stemmed woody vegetation which will normally grow to a height of
more than twenty (20) feet located on land lying between property lines of all streets, avenues and alleys belonging to the
city.
Tree topping: "Tree topping" is herein defined as the severe cutting back of tree limbs to stubs larger than three (3) inches
in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree as will remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree's crown.
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 2, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 2, 10-19-93)
Sec. 15-43. - City tree board—Established.
There is hereby created and established a "city tree board" which shall consist of seven (7) members, citizens and residents
of the city, who shall be appointed by the city commission.
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 3, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 3, 10-19-93)
Sec. 15-44. - Same—Term of office.
The term of office of the seven (7) persons appointed to the tree board shall be three (3) years. In the event that a vacancy
occurs during the term of any member, his or her successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term.
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 4, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 4, 10-19-93; Ord. No. 0-97-2, § 1, 1-21-97; Ord. No. 0-99-56, § 1, 12-
21-99)
Sec. 15-45. - Same—Compensation.
Members of the tree board shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 5, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 5, 10-19-93)
Sec. 15-46. - Same—Duties and responsibilities.
It shall be the responsibility of the tree board to study, investigate, develop and update periodically a written plan for the
care, preservation, pruning, planting, removal and disposition of the trees on city property and city cemeteries, the "Official
Comprehensive Tree Plan for the City of Cordele." The tree board, when requested by the city commission, shall consider,
investigate, make findings, and report and recommend concerning any special matter or question within the scope of its
duties.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
231/489
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 6, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 6, 10-19-93; Ord. No. 0-99-56, § 2, 12-21-99)
Sec. 15-47. - Same—Operation.
The tree board shall choose its own officers, make its own bylaws, and shall keep and preserve minutes of its proceedings.
A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of the tree board's duties under this article. The presiding
officer of the board shall be allowed to vote on all matters coming before the board.
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 7, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 7, 10-19-93)
Sec. 15-48. - Public tree care.
The city has the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees located on city property (avenues, streets, alleys and other
public areas) as may be necessary to carry out the spirit and intent of this article. The city may, but is not hereby obligated,
to remove, or cause to be removed, any tree which interferes with or might affect the operation of sewers, electric lines,
communication lines, cable television lines, or other public improvements, or trees which are infected with fungus, insects,
or other pests.
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 8, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 8, 10-19-93)
Sec. 15-49. - Tree topping.
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or city employee to top any street tree or park tree on city property.
Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or trees under wires or other improvements where pruning practices are
impractical may be exempted from provisions of this article by the city manager.
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 9, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 9, 10-19-93)
Sec. 15-50. - Reserved.
Editor's note—
Ord. No. 0-99-56, § 3, adopted Dec. 21, 1999, repealed § 15-50 of the Code in its entirety, which pertained to removal of
stumps and derived from Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 10, adopted May 18, 1993; and Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 10, adopted Oct. 19, 1993.
Sec. 15-51. - Interference illegal.
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to prevent, delay or interfere with any activity enacted by this
article.
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 11, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 11, 10-19-93)
Sec. 15-52. - Review by the city commission.
The city commission shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the tree board. Any citizen of the city
may appeal any determination made by the tree board to the city commission, which may hear the matter and make a
binding final decision.
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 12, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 12, 10-19-93)
Sec. 15-53. - Penalty.
Any person violating any provision of the article, shall, upon conviction in the Cordele Municipal Court, be punished
within the discretion of the judge of said court within the limits provided by the Charter of the City of Cordele.
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 13, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 13, 10-19-93)
Sec. 15-54. - Severability.
Should any provision of this article, or any part thereof, be found to be unconstitutional or illegal by a court of competent
jurisdiction, the remaining provisions, and parts thereof, shall remain of full force and effect.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
232/489
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 14, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 15, 10-19-93)
Sec. 15-55. - Repeal of conflicting provisions.
All ordinances and parts of ordinances, and all provisions and parts thereof in the Code of the City of Cordele, which
conflict with this article are hereby expressly repealed.
(Ord. No. 0-93-6, § 15, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 0-93-23, § 16, 10-19-93)
Chapter 16 - TAXATION
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) ---
Cross reference— Excise tax on malt beverages, § 3-41 et seq.; excise tax on wine, § 3-62; excise tax on distilled spirits, §
3-84; business license taxes, § 6-31 et seq.; depository financial institutions business license tax, § 6-61 et seq.; public
accommodations levies, § 6-81 et seq.
State Law reference— Taxation power of municipal governments, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 4, par. 1; limitation on taxing
power of municipalities, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 8; ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-2; municipal
taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.; specific business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 16-1. - Ad valorem taxes—Levied.
(a)
All property located in the city, both personal and real, subject to taxation for state or county purposes, shall be assessed for
city property taxes at the rate of 11.31 mils on forty (40) percent of the fair market value of such property as established by
the county tax assessors.
(b)
The proceeds from such ad valorem tax shall be used by the city to pay the costs of ordinary current operating expenses;
for the retirement of principal and interest on outstanding commitments; and for any other purpose now or hereafter
authorized by the constitution and laws of the state.
(c)
Such tax shall be collected for the calendar year at such times, including installment payments, as are provided by this
Code or city ordinance. Penalties and interest for late payment shall be as provided by this Code, city ordinance and/or the
laws of the state.
(Ord. No. 0-88-12, §§ 1—3, 6-29-88; Ord. No. 0-93-22, § 1, 10-19-93; Ord. No. 0-95-36, § 1, 9-19-95; Ord. No. 0-96-21, §
1, 10-15-96; Ord. No. 0-97-11, § 2, 10-7-97; Ord. No. 0-98-30, § 1, 10-6-98; Ord. No. 0-99-51, 10-19-99; Ord. No. 0-00-
31, § 2, 10-17-00)
Sec. 16-2. - Same—Assessment.
(a)
All property located in the city which is subject to taxation for state and county purposes shall be assessed as of January
first of each year according to values established by the county tax assessors.
(b)
A 11.31 mil ad valorem tax as set by the city council from time to time is herewith levied upon such property for general
fund operations of the city.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
233/489
(Ord. No. 0-85-20, §§ 1, 2, 7-26-85; Ord. No. 0-93-22, § 1, 10-19-93; Ord. No. 0-95-36, § 1, 9-19-95; Ord. No. 0-96-21, §
1, 10-15-96; Ord. No. 0-97-11, § 2, 10-7-97; Ord. No. 0-98-30, § 1, 10-6-98; Ord. No. 0-99-51, 10-19-99; Ord. No. 0-00-
31, § 2, 10-17-00)
Sec. 16-3. - Same—Interest and penalty.
All ad valorem taxes due the city under this chapter shall be subject to the maximum interest and penalty for late payment
allowed by the laws of the state. Such interest and penalty shall apply if and when applicable to installment payments.
(Ord. No. 0-85-20, § 5, 7-26-85)
Sec. 16-4. - Same—Installments.
(a)
Ad valorem taxes in the city on tangible property, other than motor vehicles, shall be due and payable in installments on
September first and December twentieth or as provided by state law of each calendar year.
(b)
For the purposes of subsection (a) above, taxes due and payable in installments on such property shall be as follows:
(1)
Sixty (60) percent of the taxes levied on the property for the preceding tax year or sixty (60) percent of the taxes based on
the preliminary digest, if available, shall be due and payable at the time of the first installment and the remaining taxes
shall be due and payable at the time of the final installment.
(2)
Those taxes due on the final installment, which shall be not later than December twentieth or as provided by state law of
each year, shall be the total taxes due on the property for the current year after credit has been given for tax payments made
in accordance with subsection (1) above.
(3)
Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to impose any liability for the payment of any ad valorem taxes upon
any person for property which was not owned on the first day of January of the applicable tax year.
(c)
Taxes not paid when due under any installment required by this section shall bear interest at the rate of one (1) percent per
month from the date the tax is due until the date the tax is paid. For the purpose of this subsection any period of less than
one (1) month shall be considered to be one (1) month. Such one (1) percent rate is based upon provisions of O.C.G.A. §
91A-239.2, and shall automatically be revised as such section may be amended; however, in no event shall the interest
provided by this subsection be less than the maximum rate allowed by any provision of the general laws of the state. An
installment shall become delinquent and subject to the interest provided by this subsection on the day following its
appropriate due date.
(d)
All taxes which are delinquent on the day following the final installment due date of December twentieth or as provided by
state law shall be subject to a penalty of five (5) percent of the principal amount thereof. Such penalty shall be in addition
to any interest provided by this section on delinquent taxes.
(Ord. No. 0-80-55, §§ 1—4, 12-16-80)
State law reference— Penalty for overdue installment payments, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-23.
Sec. 16-5. - Bills, prepayment, delinquency.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
234/489
(a)
Tax bills. Tax bills shall be mailed to taxpayers as soon as practicable after the county tax appraisers have completed their
equalization and the ad valorem tax mill rate has been set by the city commission.
(b)
Prepayment of taxes. The city commission may, by resolution, set a prepayment discount on ad valorem taxes in order to
encourage early payment of taxes.
(c)
Penalty for late payment of taxes. Penalty for late payment of taxes shall be the maximum provided by the applicable
general laws on the subject.
(d)
Collections of delinquent taxes. All methods of collection of delinquent taxes enumerated in section 4.14 of the Charter of
the city shall be used in the collection of any such delinquent taxes.
(Code 1977, § 20-2)
Sec. 16-6. - Judicial in rem ad valorem tax foreclosures.
(a)
The city commission hereby declares that the city will follow the requirements of S.B. 338 as set forth in O.C.G.A. tit. 48,
ch. 4, art. 5 relating to tax sales, regarding judicial in rem foreclosures to tax executions.
(b)
The duly appointed clerk of the city shall have the authority to commence tax foreclosure and to file petitions with the
county superior court in accordance with relating to tax sales.
(c)
The city commission therefore ordains that as provided by state law effective April 7, 1995, the city may undertake judicial
in rem tax foreclosures for delinquent taxes in the manner and under the procedures set forth in O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 4, art.
5 as the same presently exist or may hereafter be amended.
(Ord. No. 0-95-46, §§ 6—8, 12-29-95)
Secs. 16-7—16-59. - Reserved.
ARTICLE II. - SALE OF PROPERTY FOR TAXES
Sec. 16-60. - Purpose of article.
It is the intent and purpose of this Article II to carry into effect the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-5-359, as the same may
hereafter be amended or substituted, to provide for the time, place, and manner of sale of property for taxes due the city;
purchase of property by the city; recitals in tax deeds prima-facie correct; and, distribution and retention of proceeds of
sale.
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
Sec. 16-61. - Tax fi.fa.; authorized officer to issue; filing.
The city clerk shall issue fi.fa.'s on delinquent city taxes, penalty and interest as soon after December 20, or such later time
as may be provided by law for due date of city taxes, and each such fi.fa. shall be filed with the Clerk of Superior Court of
Crisp County, Georgia, for entry in the General Execution Docket maintained in the said clerk's office.
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
235/489
Sec. 16-62. - List of fi.fa.'s; furnishing list to the commission; time.
The city clerk shall make an alphabetical list of tax fi.fa.'s issued or proposed to be issued each year and deliver such list to
the city commission not later than April 1 of each year.
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
Sec. 16-63. - Review of list by commission.
The city commission shall review the fi.fa. list each year and direct the city clerk to advertise such property for taxes, as the
commission in its sound discretion determines to be in the economic interest of the city.
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
Sec. 16-64. - Notices and advertising; flow chart.
The following is a "flow chart" for notices and advertising required by this article before conducting tax sales:
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
236/489
TAX SALE FLOW CHART
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
Sec. 16-65. - Time and place for tax sales.
Tax sales for property for taxes due to the city shall be held in Room 224, City Hall, 501 North 7th Street, Cordele, Crisp
County, Georgia. Sales shall be conducted on dates and at times set forth in O.C.G.A. § 9-13-161.
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
Sec. 16-66. - Authorized officer to conduct sales.
The chief of police of the City of Cordele is hereby authorized to levy on fi.fa.'s and conduct the sales for taxes due
provided by this article.
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
Sec. 16-67. - Sales to highest bidder for cash; sales to the city; tax deeds.
(a)
Sales of property for taxes due shall be made to the highest bidder for cash.
(b)
If, during any sale of property under this Article, and after the property has been offered for a reasonable time, no one
present at the sale bids an amount for the property being sold which is as much as the total of the tax due plus the officer's
cost due on the sale, then the city manager or the assistant city manager may purchase the property for the city.
(c)
The chief of police shall make and deliver a tax deed to the successful bidder. If the city purchases the property the chief of
police shall make a tax deed to the city and deliver the same to the city manager or the assistant city manager.
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
Sec. 16-68. - City acquired property, sale.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
237/489
Property acquired by the city pursuant to section 16-67(b), (c) may be divested or alienated by the city only by public sale
of the property to the highest bidder in the same manner as sales of any other city property.
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
Sec. 16-69. - Commission may quitclaim property.
When it is clearly shown to the city commission that returned or un-returned property has been sold and purchased by the
city to protect both the taxes of the city and the cost of collecting such taxes and that the city commission has not parted
with title to property, the city commission may quitclaim the property by unanimous vote to the owner of the property at
the time of purchase by the city or to the owner's administrators, executors, heirs, or assigns upon payment of all taxes
which are due on the property and all costs due by reason of the sale.
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
Sec. 16-70. - Funds from sales.
The chief of police and other officers of the city whose duty it is to collect the taxes and other revenues of the city by levy
and sale shall be subject to be ruled for money in the hands of the officer arising from the public sale of any property
pursuant to process issued by the city. Action pursuant to this article may be taken in the Superior Court of Crisp County
and shall be accomplished in the same manner as sheriffs and constables are ruled for the distribution of money coming
into their hands from the sale of property.
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
Sec. 16-71. - Disposition of sale proceeds.
When an execution is placed in the hands of the chief of police or other selling officer of the city with written notice to
retain the proceeds arising from the sale of any property of the defendant in fi.fa., the chief of police or other selling officer,
after first paying to the city the amount due on the process under which the sale was made, shall retain the balance of the
funds in his hands until he is ordered by the court first acquiring jurisdiction under proper proceedings to pay out the funds.
Such balance of funds shall be deposited in an interest bearing account known as "Cordele Chief of Police Tax Trust
Account" and shall be audited in the same manner as any other city account.
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
Sec. 16-72. - Recitals in tax deeds.
The recitals in a deed under a sale for city taxes shall be prima-facie evidence of the facts recited in the deed.
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
Sec. 16-73. - Summons of garnishment.
(a)
When the finance officer of the city or other person authorized to collect the taxes due the city can find no property of the
defendant on which to levy a tax execution, he shall make an entry to that effect on the execution and may then issue
summons of garnishment without making affidavit or giving bond against any person he believes is indebted to the
defendant or who he believes has property, money, or effects of the defendant in his hands. The summons of garnishment
shall be served by the finance officer or sheriff of the county in which the garnishee resides at least fifteen (15) days before
the sitting of the superior court of Crisp County, and shall be returned to such court.
(b)
The finance officer or other person authorized to collect taxes shall enter on the execution the name of the person garnished
and shall return the execution to the court. The subsequent proceedings on the garnishment shall be the same as on
garnishments in cases when judgment has been obtained. (O.C.G.A. § 48-5-361)
(Ord. No. 0-94-1, 2-1-94)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
238/489
Chapter 17 - TRAFFIC
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) ---
Cross reference— Municipal court, Ch. 11; criminal trespass by motor vehicle, § 12-9; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 15;
vehicles for hire, Ch. 19.
State Law reference— Authority to provide devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(a)(4);
Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371; adoption
of uniform rules of the road by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-65-372; prosecution of traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-1
et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 17-1. - Adoption of Uniform Rules of the Road.
(a)
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372 of that title known as the Uniform Rules of the Road and the definitions contained in
O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this city with like effect as if recited herein, in
addition to the regulations contained in this chapter.
(b)
Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of such title
shall be punished as provided in section 1-13 of this Code.
(Code 1977, § 21-1)
Sec. 17-2. - Definitions.
In addition to the definitions in O.C.G.A. § 68A-101, the following definitions shall apply:
Freight curb loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or
unloading of freight or passengers.
Traffic division means the traffic division of the police department of this city, or in the event a traffic division is not
established, such term whenever used herein shall refer to the police department of this city.
(Code 1977, § 21-2)
Sec. 17-3. - Chief of police to designate crosswalks, etc.
The chief of police is hereby authorized to:
(1)
Designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections
where in his opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as he may
deem necessary.
(2)
Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of
pedestrians.
(3)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
239/489
Make lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as he may deem advisable, consistent with this chapter and any
traffic ordinances of this city.
(4)
Determine and designate by proper signs places not exceeding one hundred (100) feet in length in which the stopping,
standing or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic.
(5)
Erect signs indicating no parking upon that side of any street adjacent to any school property when such parking would, in
his opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation.
(6)
Erect signs indicating no parking upon any street when the width of the roadway does not exceed twenty (20) feet, or upon
one (1) side of a street as indicated by such signs when the width of the roadway does not exceed thirty (30) feet.
(Code 1977, § 21-3)
Sec. 17-4. - Accident reports.
The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person or property damage to an
apparent extent of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or more, shall immediately by the quickest means of communication
either verbal or written give notice of such accident to the police department if such accident occurs within this city.
(Code 1977, § 21-4)
State law reference— Duty to report accident resulting in injury, death or property damage, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-274.
Sec. 17-5. - Coasters; roller skates and similar devices, use restricted.
No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device, shall go upon any
roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk; when so crossing, such person shall be granted all of the rights and
shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. This section shall not apply upon any street while set aside as
a play street as authorized by ordinance of this city.
(Code 1977, § 21-5)
Sec. 17-6. - Riding bicycles on sidewalks prohibited.
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle on any sidewalk in the city.
(Code 1977, § 21-6)
Sec. 17-7. - Driving through processions.
No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are
in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in this chapter. This provision shall not apply at
intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic-control signals or police officers.
(Code 1977, § 21-8)
State law reference— Preventing or disrupting lawful procession, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34; operation of motorcycles and
motor vehicles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7; funeral processions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-76.
Sec. 17-8. - Driving in processions.
Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the roadway as practical and shall
follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practical and safe.
(Code 1977, § 21-9)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
240/489
Sec. 17-9. - Funeral processions to be identified.
A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified as such by the display upon the outside of each vehicle
of a pennant or other identifying insignia or by such other method as may be determined and designated by the chief of
police.
(Code 1977, § 21-10)
Sec. 17-10. - Logs securely fastened to vehicle.
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul logs and other heavy timbers through the streets of the city without having such
logs or timbers securely fastened to the trucks or other vehicles of conveyance, with chains securely fastened to prevent
such logs or timbers from falling or rolling from such vehicles.
(Code 1977, § 21-11)
Sec. 17-11. - U-turns.
(a)
It shall be unlawful for any person driving or operating an automobile, truck or other motor vehicle of every kind and
character on the streets of the city, to drive or operate such motor vehicle in such a manner as to execute a "U-turn" within
the right-of-way of such streets, except that it shall not be unlawful to execute a "U-turn" at the end of a dead-end street
where there is no other means of egress.
(b)
For the purpose of this section the word "U-turn" shall mean the reversal of the forward motion of any motor vehicle so as
to turn such motor vehicle in its forward motion within the right-of-way of any street and proceed forward in the opposite
direction upon the street being traveled.
(Code 1977, § 21-12)
State law reference— U-turns, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-121.
Sec. 17-12. - Area forbidden to trucks.
It shall be unlawful for any truck, other than what is commonly known as a pickup truck, to be upon the streets or alleys of
the city in the area between, but not including, Sixteenth Avenue and Twenty-fourth Avenue, except as hereinafter
provided:
(1)
Unless such truck is making a delivery in such area.
(2)
Unless such truck is within such area to pick up cargo of some sort, "cargo" as used herein not to include human
passengers.
(3)
Unless such truck is the property of a person in such area, and is going to or from the location of the residence of such
owner or the business place of such owner in such area.
(4)
Unless such truck is being used by the driver thereof to go to and from his personal residence which is located in such area.
(5)
Unless such truck is within such area upon a street or avenue which has been designated a state or federal highway.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
241/489
(Code 1977, § 21-18)
Sec. 17-13. - Vehicles prohibited in parks, playgrounds, on sidewalks.
(a)
It shall be unlawful to operate any motor vehicle upon any park, playground, or sidewalk owned by the city, with the
following exceptions:
(1)
Emergency medical vehicles.
(2)
Fire vehicles.
(3)
Police vehicles.
(4)
Maintenance and garbage collection vehicles and vehicles owned by contractors performing work for the city upon
property of the city.
(b)
Upon conviction of a violation of this section in the municipal court, the offender may be punished as provided in section
1-13 of this Code. If the offender is a repeat violator of this section, the motor vehicle used in the offense may be
impounded in the discretion of the judge for a period up to ninety (90) days.
(Code 1977, § 21-19)
Sec. 17-14. - Provisions saved from repeal.
(a)
The provisions of the 1977 Code relating to parades and parade permits set forth in section 21-7 are not repealed and shall
continue in full force and effect pending a revision of the subject matter by the city.
(b)
An official copy of the provision referred to in subsection (a) is on file in the city clerk's office.
Sec. 17-15. - One-hour parking in certain areas.
(a)
Parking on the north side of the 100 east block of Ninth Avenue in the City of Cordele is hereby limited to a maximum
time of one (1) hour.
(b)
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle in the areas described in subsection (a), above, for longer than one
(1) hour.
(c)
Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section in the Cordele Municipal Court shall be subject on the
first offense to a fine of ten dollars ($10.00); if the violation is found to be a second offense in said court, the fine shall be
twenty-five dollars ($25.00); and, if the violation is found to be a third offense, or more, in said court, then the violator
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
242/489
shall be punished by the judge of said court within the limits set forth in section 7.03 of the Charter of the City of Cordele
(Ga.L., 1969, pp. 3850, 3851).
(Ord. No. 0-04-19, § 1, 7-20-04)
Cross reference— Parking, § 17-51 et seq.
Sec. 17-16. - Blocking ingress and egress.
It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to block or interfere with the free ingress and egress to any private or public
property.
(Ord. No. 0-95-35, 9-19-95)
Sec. 17-17. - Remaining on business property without permission.
It shall be unlawful for any person to remain upon the premises or parking areas of any business after 7:00 p.m. without the
consent of the owner or operator of the business involved. If a common parking area is used by more than one (1) business,
the consent of each owner or operator of each such business involved shall be required.
(Ord. No. 0-95-35, 9-19-95)
Secs. 17-18—17-30. - Reserved.
ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC SCHEDULES
Sec. 17-31. - Definition.
As used in this article, "traffic schedule" means the official list or schedule of the regulations maintained in the office of the
city clerk, including the following:
(1)
Designating the location of traffic-control devices.
(2)
Designating areas or zones where regulations are applied to parking, loading, bus stops or taxicab stands.
(3)
Restricting or regulating traffic at certain times on certain streets or to certain types, weights or sizes of vehicles.
(4)
Designating the location of through streets, stop intersections, yield-right-of-way intersections, waiting lanes, one-way
streets or truck traffic routes.
(5)
Establishing regulations upon vehicle turns at designated locations.
(Ord. No. 0-94-3, § 1, 5-3-94)
Sec. 17-32. - Enumerated.
Pursuant to the applicable sections of this chapter, the following traffic schedules are on file and maintained in the clerk's
office:
(1)
One-way streets and alleys. Certain streets and alleys or portions of streets and alleys within the city are hereby designated
as one-way streets, and travel along or upon the designated streets shall be in the direction indicated.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
243/489
(2)
School zones. During the hours from 8:00 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. on Mondays through Fridays during the school term for and
in the city beginning on the first Monday in each September and ending on the last Friday in May, the speed limit shall be
as prescribed in the speed or safety zones designated in the traffic schedule.
(3)
Speed limits. Speed limits are hereby established for certain streets and portions of streets.
(4)
Through streets. Certain streets or portions thereof are hereby designated as through streets.
Sec. 17-33. - Speed limits.

ARTICLE III. - PARKING
Sec. 17-51. - Impounding of illegally parked vehicles.
(a)
Any motor vehicle parked within a forbidden zone or forbidden area within the city is illegally parked and is declared to be
a public nuisance and any such motor vehicle found to be illegally parked may be removed and impounded.
(b)
A fee or service charge in the amount of the actual towing charge shall be paid by the owner of any such impounded
vehicle to secure its release.
(c)
Any such motor vehicle illegally parked may summarily be removed and impounded without having a judicial
determination as to whether or not such illegal parking was in fact a nuisance. However, any owner of an impounded motor
vehicle may appeal the impounding of his vehicle to the municipal court by posting a cash or property bond in the amount
of the actual towing charge.
(Code 1977, § 21-31)
Sec. 17-52. - Unlawful purposes.
No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway or alley for the principal purpose of:
(1)
Displaying such vehicle for sale.
(2)
Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle except repairs necessitated by an emergency.
(Code 1977, § 21-32)
Sec. 17-53. - Storing of vehicles on streets.
(a)
It shall be unlawful for any person to use the streets of the city for the storing of any motor vehicle and any continuing
violation of this section from day to day shall constitute a new and separate violation.
(b)
For the purpose of this section the word "storing" shall not mean the mere act of permitting an automobile or any other
motor vehicle to remain parked or standing, within authorized parking areas or spaces, on the streets of the city between
intermittent periods of use, but shall mean the parking or standing, in any place or manner whatsoever, on the streets of the
city of a motor vehicle not in operation for intermittent periods of use and movement.
(Code 1977, § 21-32)
Cross reference— Abandoned vehicles, § 14-41 et seq.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
252/489
State law reference— Abandoned automobiles as solid waste, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-22(11); authority to provide by ordinance
for removal and disposal of junked vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4; when police officers may remove vehicles, O.C.G.A. §
40-6-206; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq.; removal of improperly parked cars, O.C.G.A. § 44-1-13.
Sec. 17-54. - Residential parking of trucks, trailers, vans, etc.—Prohibited.
It shall be unlawful in a residential zone (R-12, R-7.5S, R-7-5, R-4) to park the following types of vehicles on the public
rights-of-way of the city or upon privately-owned property within three hundred (300) feet from the nearest portion of a
structure used as a permanent residence.
(1)
Any vehicle normally requiring or having more than four (4) wheels.
(2)
Any vehicle specifically designed, or modified, to tow trailers, mobile homes, vans or similar vehicles.
(3)
All trailers, mobile homes, vans or similar vehicles.
(Code 1977, § 21-34; Ord. No. 0-79-36, § I, 10-16-79; Ord. No. 0-79-36, § I(21-34), 11-6-79)
Sec. 17-55. - Same—Exception.
There shall be excepted from the provisions of section 17-54 any vehicle which is:
(1)
Loading or unloading goods or merchandise for residential purposes incident to the specific residence where such loading
or unloading occurs.
(2)
Making minor emergency repairs.
(Code 1977, § 21-35; Ord. No. 0-79-33, § 2, 10-16-79; Ord. No. 0-79-36, § II, 11-6-79)
Sec. 17-56. - Same—Compliance with law by excepted vehicles.
Any motorized vehicle which is excepted under section 17-55 shall comply with any other provision of this Code or city
ordinance regarding noise, abandoned vehicles or other provisions.
(Code 1977, § 21-36; Ord. No. 0-79-33, § 3, 10-16-79)
Sec. 17-57. - Intent.
It is the express legislative intent of this article to promote vehicular safety in the city as well as to promote the safety of
persons who might otherwise be killed or injured by reduced visibility on public ways of the city and from excessive
movement of large vehicles to and from private property in residential areas of the city.
(Ord. No. 0-79-33, § 4, 10-16-79)
Sec. 17-58. - Penalty.
Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this article upon trial in the municipal court of the city shall be
punished in accordance with section 1-13.
(Ord. No. 0-79-33, § 5, 10-16-79)
Sec. 17-59. - Prohibited on Sixteenth Avenue.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
253/489
It shall be unlawful to park (attended or unattended) any vehicle on Sixteenth Avenue in the city.
(Ord. No. 0-83-15, § 1, 6-7-83)
Sec. 17-60. - Restricted on Seventh Street.
(a)
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle, tractor, trailer or any other device operating on wheels or tracks, occupied or
unoccupied, attended or unattended, upon that portion of Seventh Street North located between Eighth Avenue and the
north city limits.
(b)
The erection of signs notifying the public that no parking is permitted on such section of Seventh Street North is hereby
authorized. Such signs shall be placed at reasonable intervals and shall conform to requirements of law and D.O.T.
regulations.
(Ord. No. 0-88-14, §§ 1, 2, 7-19-88)
Secs. 17-61—17-80. - Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. - RAILROADS
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) ---
State Law reference— Railroad companies, O.C.G.A. § 46-8-1 et seq.
Sec. 17-81. - Definitions.
For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them:
Train means and includes a railroad engine or propelling unit with or without cars attached, and shall include two (2) or
more railroad cars when attached together, whether or not there shall be an engine or propelling unit attached thereto.
Vehicular traffic means all motorized traffic upon the streets of the city, not including trains or railroad cars.
(Code 1977, § 21-50)
Sec. 17-82. - Blocking streets—Combined time of moving and while stopped.
It shall be a violation of this article for the directing officer or the operator of any railroad train to direct the operation of or
to operate the same so that it shall stop in an intersection with a public street within the city longer than ten (10) minutes
including the time such train is in motion and the time such train is stopped.
(Code 1977, § 21-51)
Sec. 17-83. - Same—Leaving crossing gates down.
It shall be a violation of this article for any railroad company or corporation to allow crossing gates maintained or operated
by such company or corporation at any intersection of its tracks with any street in the city to remain down so as to control
traffic upon any such street for an uninterrupted period of time longer than ten (10) minutes, regardless of whether or not a
train or railroad car is, or has been, within the area of such intersection within such period of time.
(Code 1977, § 21-52)
Sec. 17-84. - Same—Leaving warning device activated.
It shall be a violation of this article for any railroad company or corporation to allow any warning device maintained or
operated by such company or corporation and installed to control vehicular traffic at any intersection of its tracks with any
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
254/489
street of the city to remain active so as to control vehicular traffic upon any such street for an uninterrupted period of time
longer than ten (10) minutes, regardless of whether or not a train or trains, or railroad car or cars are, or have been, within
the area of such intersection within such period of time.
(Code 1977, § 21-53)
Sec. 17-85. - Same—Switching or other intra-city transit.
It shall be a violation of this article for the directing officer or the operator of any railroad train to direct the operation of or
to operate the same while engaged in local switching or any other intra-city transit in such a manner as to prevent the use of
any street within the city for purposes of travel for a period of time longer than five (5) minutes.
(Code 1977, § 21-54)
Sec. 17-86. - Same—Clearing in case of fire alarm.
In case of fire alarms, railroad crossings shall immediately be cleared.
(Code 1977, § 21-55)
Sec. 17-87. - Area where leaving cars uncoupled prohibited.
It shall be a violation of this article for any officer or employee of any railroad company or corporation or any other person
to leave railroad cars uncoupled from propelling unit or units in that space contained in Eleventh Street, Seventh Street,
Sixth Street, Third Street, Second Street, First Street, Sixteenth Avenue or Twenty-fourth Avenue, in the city, including the
sidewalks along the sides of such streets.
(Code 1977, § 21-56)
Sec. 17-88. - Flagman during switching, etc.
It shall be a violation of this article for any railroad officer or employee in charge of any train passing through the city to
allow such train to be switched, "made up," or drilled within the city, without having a flagman or brakeman placed in front
of the engine or train of cars, the term "front," as used herein to mean the foremost unit, whether powered or not, in the
direction of travel of such train.
(Code 1977, § 21-57)
Sec. 17-89. - "Kicking" cars or "flying switch."
It shall be a violation of this article for any employee or officer of a railroad to "kick" cars, or perform what is known in
railroad parlance as "the flying switch" on any main line or side track or railroad yard in the city.
(Code 1977, § 21-58)
Sec. 17-90. - Crossings to be kept in repair.
(a)
It shall be the duty of all railroad companies running or operating a line of railroad in and through the city to place and
keep in good repair all street crossings by placing plank, other timbers or other approved materials on each side of the rails
of the roads and the rails of each side track so as to raise the entire space of the crossings between the rails to the level of
the rails and fill in between the tracks of the roads or side tracks with gravel, asphalt or other approved material, for the
whole space of the streets and sidewalks across which such tracks may run or operate so as to render the same of safe and
easy passage to pedestrians and vehicles of all kinds.
(b)
Should any railroad company or corporation owning or operating a line of railroad through the city fail or refuse to place or
keep in good repair any street crossing on its line of road within the city, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to give
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
255/489
the agent of the company or corporation, so defaulting, notice in writing or otherwise, that within ten (10) days, the city
will proceed to have such work executed at the expense of the railroad company or corporation.
(c)
The person opening or repairing such crossings shall, as soon as the work is completed, render to the city clerk an itemized,
sworn statement of the cost of such work, whereupon the clerk shall immediately issue an execution for said amount
against the defaulting corporation, which shall be levied by the chief of police and the property sold by him under the same
rules and regulations as govern judicial sales.
(Code 1977, § 21-59)
Sec. 17-91. - Persons permitted to get on or off trains.
It shall be unlawful for any person other than passengers to get on or off any train within the city while such train is in
motion or otherwise except on business.
(Code 1977, § 21-60)
Sec. 17-92. - Excused acts.
No act which is caused by breakdown of equipment or other mishap, nor any act done to prevent personal injuries or
property damage, shall be a violation of this article.
(Code 1977, § 21-62)
Chapter 18 - UTILITIES

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 18-1. - Designated fireplug for public use.
The fireplug immediately behind the city hall on the Sixth—Eighth Avenue connector is hereby designated as the only
fireplug in the city from which the public is authorized to draw and use city water.
(1)
A backflow prevention device shall be installed on such fireplug which will impede the backflow of any residues into the
city water system.
(2)
A water meter shall also be installed at the fireplug.
(3)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
256/489
Any person desiring to fill tankers, trucks, or any other container from such fireplug shall make prior arrangements with the
city and shall pay a fee as determined by the city commission from time to time and listed in the schedule of fees and
charges maintained in the city clerk's office plus the regular user rate for water (as indicated by the meter) for each "fill up."
(4)
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a city employee acting within the scope of his authority, to violate any
provision of this section.
(5)
Any person violating any provision of this section shall, after conviction in the municipal court be punished within the
limits set forth in section 1-13 of this Code.
(Ord. No. 0-84-23, § 22-2.1, 8-21-84)
Sec. 18-2. - Grease traps required.
(a)
As used in this section the following terms shall have the meaning's respectively ascribed to them:
Grease trap means a device used to filter grease from wastewater entering the city sewer system. It is attached to the
property owner's service line (on the property owner's property). The maintenance of a grease trap is the responsibility of
the property owner.
Property owner means the person owning or having control of property in the city.
(b)
Grease traps shall be installed by property owners in the city wherever the same are required by the current plumbing code
adopted and of force and effect in the city. The provisions of this subsection shall apply whether or not improvements
located upon the property owner's property are new construction. Design and specifications for such grease traps shall be
according to the plumbing code.
(c)
It shall be a violation of this section for a property owner to:
(1)
Remove a grease trap from his service line when, by the use of his property, a grease trap is required under the plumbing
code.
(2)
Fail to maintain any grease trap upon his property so that such device will afford the maximum protection from grease to
the sewer lines of the city.
(3)
Use any chemical in a grease trap which will operate adversely to the design and function of the waste water treatment
facilities of the city.
(Code 1977, § 22-12)
Secs. 18-3—18-20. - Reserved.
ARTICLE II. - FEES, DEPOSITS, RATES AND BILLING
Sec. 18-21. - Utility service deposits.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
257/489
(a)
A deposit for gas, water and sewer service in an amount determined from time to time by city commission shall be required
for residential customers and commercial service. Deposit amounts shall be listed in the schedule of fees and charges, an
official copy of which shall be available for public inspection in the office of the city clerk.
(b)
Upon any customer failing or refusing to pay his bill or any part thereof within ten (10) days after the rendition thereof, his
deposit shall be applied in payment of his bill and his connection to the water and gas system shall be shut off until such
time as all past due bills and a new deposit as above provided shall have been paid.
(c)
Upon the payment of all charges for services and facilities afforded any customer by the city utility control and treatment
department and discontinuance of such service, at his request, the deposit theretofore made by him shall be refunded
without interest.
(Code 1977, § 22-7)
Sec. 18-22. - Gas, water and sewer bills; dates due and delinquent; discontinuance of service for nonpayment.
(a)
Payment for gas, water and sewer service shall be due and payable to the finance department upon terms and billings as
presently presented, or by changes announced to customers in writing sixty (60) days prior to the effective dates of such
changes in due dates, cut off dates, and grace periods. Any person who fails to pay any such billing by the cut off date shall
be subject to a penalty as specified in the fee schedule. Any person who has had a service cut off for nonpayment, and who
desires to have the service reconnected, shall pay an additional fee as set forth in the fee schedule for such reconnection.
(b)
Any person who has not paid for gas, water and sewer service, and collection is instituted by the city or the city's collection
agency shall be required to pay the aforesaid penalties, together with such collection fees and interest as are set forth in the
fee schedule.
(Code 1977, § 22-6; Ord. No. 0-98-4, § 1, 2-3-98; Ord. No. 0-07-08, § 1, 4-17-07)
Sec. 18-23. - Charge for dishonored checks given to city.
Every person who shall issue to the city a check in purported payment of utility charges, or in payment of any other
obligation to the city, shall pay a fee as set forth in the fee schedule if such check is dishonored for payment by the bank
upon which the same is drawn. For the purposes of this section charges for water, sewer service, gas and garbage collection
shall be construed as "utility charges." If the check is in purported payment of utility charges, and should the user fail to
make such dishonored check good and pay the fee as set forth in the fee schedule promptly, the user shall be mailed a
notice that utility services involved shall be discontinued in ten (10) days, but that if the user contends that the charges or
the fee are improper for any reason, the user has a right to a hearing before the cut-off date as provided by sections 18-51
through 18-61, inclusive.
(Ord. No. 0-87-8, § 22-13, 5-19-87)
Sec. 18-24. - Unclaimed utility deposits and funds.
(a)
Any deposit made by a subscriber with a city utility to secure payment for or any sum paid in advance for utility services to
be furnished by the city, together with any credits carried on the records of the city due to any such subscriber, less any
lawful deductions, that have remained unclaimed by the person appearing on the records of the city entitled thereto for
more than seven (7) years after the termination of the services for which the deposit or advanced payment was made, shall
be paid over into the general fund of the city, and the account of any such subscriber closed. For the purposes of this
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
258/489
section, the term "person" shall be construed to be inclusive of a firm, corporation, association, organization, and every
other entity subscribing to city utilities.
(b)
The finance director of the city shall, by written order for each subscriber whose funds are subject to this section, effect the
transfers to the general fund authorized by this section. Such orders shall indicate that they are pursuant to section 18-24 of
this Code; the amount of the deposit and credits, if any, of the city utility subscriber being transferred to the general fund;
that there has been no written request for such funds by the subscriber for more than seven (7) years; that city utilities have
not been provided for such subscriber for more than seven (7) years; that the present address and whereabouts of the
subscriber is unknown; and the date of the transfer of the funds to the general fund of the city. Such orders shall be
maintained by the finance director in the permanent records of the city.
(Ord. No. 0-86-29, § 22-13, 10-21-86)
Sec. 18-25. - Water and sewer service rate schedule.
The water and sewer rates for users of such services provided by the city shall be as set forth in the fee schedule.
(Code 1977, § 22-2; Ord. No. 0-94-14, 9-22-94)
Sec. 18-26. - Water and sewer connection fees.
All persons who are connecting to the city water supply or the city sewer system shall pay a fee as set forth in the fee
schedule.
(Code 1977, § 22-3)
Sec. 18-27. - Water and sewer line extension fees.
In addition to the water and sewer connection fees, all persons requesting water line or sewer line connections shall pay a
fee as set forth in the fee schedule.
(Code 1977, § 22-4)
Sec. 18-28. - Minimum standards for water and sewer line extensions.
(a)
The city shall be responsible to bring the water and sewer service to the property line of the customer in accordance with
the water and sewer connection fees prescribed in the fee schedule.
(b)
A written agreement evidencing the customer's legal obligation to pay upon completion is required of all customers
requesting water or sewer line extensions in excess of one hundred (100) feet.
(c)
Minimum size water lines for fire protection. All customers, either inside or outside the city must be within a minimum of
one thousand (1,000) feet of a fire hydrant on six-inch service.
(Code 1977, § 22-5)
Sec. 18-29. - Gas—Rates.
All persons using gas from the city gas system shall be required to pay for the quantity of gas used according to the
appropriate rate calculated on a monthly basis from the following:
(1)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
259/489
Non-interruptible rate. Actual cost of the gas to the city plus three dollars ($3.00) per M.C.F. (million cubic feet) plus an
availability rate set from time to time by resolution of the city commission and entered in the fee schedule.
(2)
Interruptible rate. Actual cost of the gas to the city plus seventy cents ($0.70) for the first five thousand (5,000) M.C.F.;
plus fifty-five cents ($0.55) per M.C.F. for the next five thousand and one (5,001) M.C.F. to fifteen thousand (15,000)
M.C.F.; plus forty cents ($0.40) per M.C.F. for all gas used each month over fifteen thousand (15,000) M.C.F.
(3)
Industrial rate. Rate for customers with a pipeline contract. Actual cost of the gas to the city plus fifteen cents ($0.15) per
M.C.F.
(Code 1977, § 22-8; Ord. No. 0-00-32, 10-12-00)
Sec. 18-30. - Same—Fees for disconnecting and reconnecting at customer's request.
(a)
In the event a residential or small commercial customer desires to have his gas service temporarily disconnected, the city
will cut off the gas to this customer. The city will turn the gas back on at the customer's request, for a fee as set forth in the
fee schedule.
(b)
For all other customers the fees for disconnection and reconnection shall be as set forth in the fee schedule.
(Code 1977, § 22-9)
Sec. 18-31. - After hours service charge for water and gas connections.
Whenever a request is made for water and gas connections at times other than during normal working hours for city office
personnel, the person making the request shall be informed that such connection is subject to a "after hours" service charge
as set forth in the fee schedule (in addition to all other regular deposits and charges), and, the requesting person shall have
the option of amending his request to a regular "business hours" connection or agreeing to pay the "after hours" service
charge. For the purposes of this section, normal working hours of city office personnel shall be construed to mean 8:00 a.m.
to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, excepting holidays and other times when office personnel are absent the city hall by
direction of the city commission.
(Ord. No. 0-87-9, § 22-14, 5-19-87)
Secs. 18-32—18-50. - Reserved.
ARTICLE III. - TERMINATION HEARINGS
Sec. 18-51. - Title.
This article shall be known as the "Utility Termination Hearing Ordinance," and may be so cited.
(Code 1977, § 22-33)
Sec. 18-52. - Notice on billing of discontinuance date.
All city utility bills (including charges for garbage collection) shall have clearly and plainly written, stamped or printed
thereupon a notice as to the date when such services shall be discontinued for nonpayment of the billed amount. Such
notice need be in no particular form or follow any particular wording, provided such notice clearly shows on its face the
cutoff date.
(Code 1977, § 22-34)
Sec. 18-53. - Reserved.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
260/489
Editor's note—
Ord. No. 0-07-08, § 2, adopted April 17, 2007, repealed § 18-53, which pertained to the second notice required prior
cessation to service.
Sec. 18-54. - Notification of hearing date, time, etc., upon request of customer.
The city manager shall establish procedures which shall insure that when a utility customer calls the city hall to schedule a
utility hearing time, such customer will be promptly notified of the date, time and place of such hearing (to include the
room number at the city hall where the hearing will be conducted), and shall further notify such customer of the person
designated as hearing officer.
(Code 1977, § 22-36)
Sec. 18-55. - Designation of hearing officer.
The city manager shall designate a hearing officer to conduct the hearings provided for by this article. Such designation
may be on a rotating basis, or the designated hearing officer may be changed from time to time, but in every instance the
hearing officer shall be a responsible city employee. In no instance may the hearing officer be an elected official of the city.
(Code 1977, § 22-37)
Sec. 18-56. - Conduct of hearing; authority of officer.
The hearings provided for by this article shall not be conspicuously conducted, i.e., they shall transpire in a relatively
private place and not in the presence of customers paying bills or city employees not involved in the determination of the
merits of the subject matter of the hearing. However, the hearing officer hereby has the authority to call for and promptly
receive all city records and all testimony of any city employees such as would tend to shed any light on the merits of the
complaining customers' contentions, the city's billing position, or any other information bearing upon the subject matter of
the hearing.
(Code 1977, § 22-38)
Sec. 18-57. - Relevant issues, evidence.
At hearings provided for by this article the only relevant issue is whether or not the complaining customer was billed for
utilities' services or garbage collection actually received, and according to the city's standard charges therefor. Evidence as
to any other matter relating to utility services or garbage collection, or any other complaint against the city, shall not be
heard.
(Code 1977, § 22-39)
Sec. 18-58. - Billing for garbage collection not based on use.
The garbage collection service, for which a city customer is billed, provides an opportunity for the city customer to deposit
garbage for collection according to ordinances, rules and regulations of the city; and, if for any reason he does not deposit
such garbage, billing for garbage collection shall nevertheless be a proper charge for services received.
(Code 1977, § 22-40)
Sec. 18-59. - Authority of hearing officer to adjust bills.
The hearing officer shall have the power to make such adjustments in the complaining customer's statement or bill as the
hearing officer may find proper from the evidence at the hearing. If the complaining customer pays the adjusted charge
before the cutoff date there shall be no termination of city services. If the complaining customer does not pay the adjusted
charges before the cutoff date city services shall be terminated; however, the adjusted charges shall prevail. If the hearing
officer determines that the complaining customer's charges are proper, services shall be terminated on the cutoff date unless
the bill or statement is paid in full prior to the cutoff date.
(Code 1977, § 22-41)
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
261/489
Sec. 18-60. - Records.
The city manager shall provide a written log in which shall be shown the name of the hearing officer, the name and address
of the complaining customer, the customer's account number, the date and time of the scheduled hearing, the determination
of the hearing officer, and a notation if the customer requesting the hearing does not appear.
(Code 1977, § 22-42)
Sec. 18-61. - Nonappearance of complainant.
If a complaining customer has not appeared within fifteen (15) minutes of the time the hearing was scheduled, the
complaining customer shall have lost his right to be heard unless such complaining customer shall show that he was
providentially prevented from being present. If the customer has not made providential excuse for his nonappearance
within one (1) hour after the scheduled hearing time, he shall thereafter have no further right of hearing whatsoever under
the provisions of this article.
(Code 1977, § 22-43)
Secs. 18-62—18-80. - Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. - WASTEWATER TREATMENT FACILITIES USER CHARGES
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 18-81. - Short title.
This article shall be known as and may be cited as the "Wastewater Treatment Facilities User Charge Ordinance."
(Ord. No. 0-80-6, § 1-A, 2-19-80)
Sec. 18-82. - Purpose.
This article establishes a user charge system to assure that each user of wastewater treatment facilities within the system
service area will pay as a minimum, its proportionate share of the costs of operation and maintenance, including
replacement of equipment, and appurtenances necessary to maintain the capacity and performance of the facilities.
(Ord. No. 0-80-6, § 1-1, 2-19-80)
Sec. 18-83. - Definitions.
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this article shall be as follows:
Abnormal strength wastewater means any wastewater with BOD and suspended solids concentrations greater than that of
normal strength wastewater but which is otherwise acceptable into a public sewer under the terms of the sewer use
ordinance.
Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter
in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius by the laboratory procedure prescribed in Standard Methods for the
Examination of Water and Wastewater. BOD shall be expressed in milligrams per liter.
Domestic wastewater discharger means any discharger not covered under the definition of "industrial wastewater
discharger."
Industrial wastewater discharger means any nongovernmental industrial or commercial establishment with a classification
as designated in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, latest edition, U.S. Office of Management and Budget and
who utilizes the wastewater treatment works of the city.
Infiltration/inflow means water other than wastewater that enters a sewerage system.
Normal strength wastewater means wastewater with BOD and suspended solids concentrations less than or equal to that
permitted by the sewer use ordinance and which is otherwise acceptable into a public sewer under the terms of the sewer
use ordinance.
5/6/2019 Cordele, GA Code of Ordinances
262/489
Suspended solids means suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in, water, wastewater or
other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in Standard Methods for the Examination of Water
and Wastewater. Suspended solids shall be expressed in milligrams per liter.
Toxic pollutants means any substance whether gaseous, liquid or solid which, when discharged to a public sewer in
sufficient concentrations, may in the opinion of the designated city representative, be hazardous to sewer maintenance and
personnel, tend to interfere with any wastewater treatment process, or to constitute a hazard to human beings or animals, or
to inhibit aquatic life, or to create a hazard to recreation in the receiving waters of the effluent from a wastewater treatment
plant.
(Ord. No. 0-80-6, § 1-2, 2-19-80)
Sec. 18-84. - Other user charges.
Charges to users under this article and in addition to other user charges levied by the city for capital costs and other
nonoperational and maintenance costs incurred in providing wastewater collection and treatment services.
(Ord. No. 0-80-6, § 1-3, 2-19-80)
Sec. 18-85. - Excess revenues.
Any excess revenues generated from operation and maintenance user charges for wastewater collection and treatment
facilities shall be applied to operation and maintenance costs for the next year. User charge rates shall be adjusted
accordingly.
(Ord. No. 0-80-6, § 1-4, 2-19-80)
Sec. 18-86. - Toxic pollutant dischargers.
Any system user which discharges any toxic pollutants which cause an increase in the cost of managing the effluent or the
sludge of the wastewater treatment facilities shall pay for such increased costs.
(Ord. No. 0-80-6, § 1-5, 2-19-80)
Sec. 18-87. - User notification.
At least annually, each system user shall be notified, in conjunction with a regular bill, of the portion of user charges which
are attributable to operation and maintenance for wastewater treatment facilities.
(Ord. No. 0-80-6, § 1-6, 2-19-80)
Secs. 18-88—18-105. - Reserved.
DIVISION 2. - OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE USER CHARGE DETERMINATION
Sec. 18-106. - Generally.
In determining user charges applicable to operation and maintenance costs of wastewater treatment facilities, consideration
will be given to each user's quantity of wastewater flow, and concentrations of BOD and suspended solids. Domestic
wastewater dischargers and industrial wastewater dischargers of normal strength wastewater shall be subject only to a basic
user charge. Industrial wastewater dischargers of abnormal strength wastewater shall be subject to an increased user charge,
reflecting their higher strength factors.
(Ord. No. 0-80-6, § 2-1, 2-19-80)
Sec. 18-107. - Basic user charge.
The basic user charge shall be computed as follows:
R = VmCT
wherein:

operation and maintenance.

Sec. 18-108. - Increased user charge.

Secs. 18-110—18-125. - Reserved.
DIVISION 3. - ADMINISTRATION
Sec. 18-126. - User discharge measurement.
Measurement of wastewater discharges by an individual user shall be carried out in the manner prescribed in the sewer use
ordinance. Measurement and analysis of industrial wastewater dischargers of abnormal strength wastewater shall be
performed at least biennially. The most recent analytical results shall be used in determining user charges for abnormal
strength wastewater dischargers.
(Ord. No. 0-80-6, § 3-1, 2-19-80)
Sec. 18-127. - Records.
The city shall maintain records to verify compliance with this article and shall accurately record all income and
expenditures resulting from or necessitated by the administration of the operation and maintenance user charge system.
(Ord. No. 0-80-6, § 3-2, 2-19-80)
Sec. 18-128. - Noncity users.
Users located outside the jurisdiction of the city, and discharging to the city's wastewater treatment facilities shall be
subject to all provisions of this article.
(Ord. No. 0-80-6, § 3-3, 2-19-80)
